An Analysis of Arithmetic Constraints on Integer Intervals

Krzysztof R. Apt
CWI, P.O. Box 94079, 1090 GB Amsterdam, the Netherlands and
University of Amsterdam, the Netherlands
Peter Zoeteweij111 The work of the second author was supported by NWO, The Netherlands Organization for Scientific Research, under project number 612.069.003.
Faculty of Electrical Engineering, Mathematics and Computer Science,
Delft University of Technology, P.O. Box 5031, 2600 GA Delft, the Netherlands
Abstract

Arithmetic constraints on integer intervals are supported in many constraint programming systems. We study here a number of approaches to implement constraint propagation for these constraints. To describe them we introduce integer interval arithmetic. Each approach is explained using appropriate proof rules that reduce the variable domains. We compare these approaches using a set of benchmarks. For the most promising approach we provide results that characterize the effect of constraint propagation.

1 Introduction

1.1 Motivation

The subject of arithmetic constraints on reals has attracted a great deal of attention in the literature. In contrast, arithmetic constraints on integer intervals have not been studied even though they are supported in a number of constraint programming systems. In fact, constraint propagation for them is present in ECLiùëñ{}^{i}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTPSeùëí{}^{e}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT italic_e end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT, SICStus Prolog, GNU Prolog, ILOG Solver and undoubtedly most of the systems that support constraint propagation for linear constraints on integer intervals. Yet, in contrast to the case of linear constraints ‚Äî see notably [14] ‚Äî we did not encounter in the literature any analysis of this form of constraint propagation.

In this paper we study these constraints in a systematic way. It turns out that in contrast to linear constraints on integer intervals there are a number of natural approaches to constraint propagation for these constraints. They differ in the extent to which the constraints are decomposed.

Even though arithmetic constraints on integer intervals need not be decomposed into atomic arithmetic constraints, as is common practice for constraints on reals, we found that it is beneficial to do so: it allows for efficient scheduling of the reduction rules and for reuse of auxiliary variables for common subterms between constraints.

It could be argued that since integer arithmetic is a special case of real arithmetic, specialized constraint propagation methods for integer arithmetic constraints are not needed. Indeed, a constraint satisfaction problem (CSP) involving arithmetic constraints on integer variables can be solved using any known method for constraints on reals, with additional constraints ensuring that the variables assume only integer values. This was suggested in¬†[6] and is implemented, for example, in RealPaver [13]. However, a dedicated study and implementation of the integer case is beneficial for a number of reasons.

  • ‚Ä¢

    In some cases the knowledge that we are dealing with integers yields a stronger constraint propagation than the approach through the constraint propagation for arithmetic constraints on reals. This can be also beneficial when we are dealing with hybrid problems that involve arithmetic constraints on both integer and real variables.

  • ‚Ä¢

    The ‚Äòindirect‚Äô approach through the reals is based on floating-point numbers, which are of limited precision. This implies that no exact representation exists for integers outside certain bounds. We believe that it should be possible to deal with large integers precisely, and that we should not revert to a floating-point representation when other options exist. Using a library like GNU MP [11] we can use arbitrary length integers (called multiple precision integers in GNU MP), whose size is limited only by the available memory.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Since arithmetic constraints on integer intervals are supported in a number of constraint programming systems, it is natural to investigate in a systematic way various approaches to their implementation. The approaches based on the integers are amenable to a clear theoretical analysis. In particular, in Section 9 and Subsection 10.1 we provide the characterization results that clarify the effect of constraint propagation for the approach that emerged in our studies as the fastest.

An example that supports the first argument is the constraint x‚ãÖy=z‚ãÖùë•ùë¶ùëßx\cdot y=zitalic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y = italic_z, where ‚àí3‚â§x‚â§33ùë•3-3\leq x\leq 3- 3 ‚â§ italic_x ‚â§ 3, ‚àí1‚â§y‚â§11ùë¶1-1\leq y\leq 1- 1 ‚â§ italic_y ‚â§ 1, and 1‚â§z‚â§21ùëß21\leq z\leq 21 ‚â§ italic_z ‚â§ 2. When all variables are integers, there are no solutions having x=3ùë•3x=3italic_x = 3 or x=‚àí3ùë•3x=-3italic_x = - 3, and the constraint propagation methods that we consider here will actually remove these values from the domain of xùë•xitalic_x. However, if these variables are considered to be reals, these values may not be removed, and solving the integer problem through constraint propagation methods for constraints on reals may lead to a larger search space.

As an indication that integer representation is not entirely a theoretical issue, consider the following benchmark from [6]. Find nùëõnitalic_n integers x1,‚Ä¶,xnsubscriptùë•1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëõx_{1},\ldots,x_{n}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, 1‚â§xi‚â§n1subscriptùë•ùëñùëõ1\leq x_{i}\leq n1 ‚â§ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ italic_n, verifying the conditions

‚àëi=1nxi=‚àëi=1ni,‚àèi=1nxi=‚àèi=1ni,x1‚â§x2‚â§‚Ä¶‚â§xn.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùë•ùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõùëñformulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptproductùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùë•ùëñsuperscriptsubscriptproductùëñ1ùëõùëñsubscriptùë•1subscriptùë•2‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëõ\sum_{i=1}^{n}x_{i}=\sum_{i=1}^{n}i,\quad\prod_{i=1}^{n}x_{i}=\prod_{i=1}^{n}i,\quad x_{1}\leq x_{2}\leq\ldots\leq x_{n}.‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i , ‚àè start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ‚àè start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ ‚Ä¶ ‚â§ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

For n=10ùëõ10n=10italic_n = 10 the initial maximum value of the left-hand side expression of the second constraint equals 1010superscript101010^{10}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 10 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which exceeds 232superscript2322^{32}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 32 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the number of values that can be represented as 32-bit integers. For n=16ùëõ16n=16italic_n = 16, there is already no signed integer representation of this bound in 64 bits.

To show that arbitrary length integers can be affordable, Table¬†1 shows timing results for three small C++ programs that solve the above benchmark via a basic branch-and-propagate search process. These programs differ only in the representation of the bounds of the variables, and in the signature of the arithmetic operations applied to these bounds: 64-bit floating point numbers (double), 64-bit integers (long long), and arbitrary length integers (using the mpz data type of the GNU MP library). The programs were compiled using the same optimization flags as the default build of the GNU MP library, and the reported CPU times are user time in seconds, measured by the time command on a 1200 MHz AMD Athlon CPU.

The results for 64-bit integers and n‚â•16ùëõ16n\geq 16italic_n ‚â• 16 could be computed by initializing the upper bound of the auxiliary variable equated to the product of all problem variables to n!ùëõn!italic_n !, which works for n<20ùëõ20n<20italic_n < 20. These results indicate that on our hardware, the 64-bit integer and floating-point implementations are equally efficient, while for these specific problem instances, the cost of using arbitrary length integers is roughly a factor four. Note that in a full-fledged constraint solver, this overhead would be far less prominent, because compared to these small C++ programs, a large part of the execution time is spent in the framework that coordinates the computation (cf. the results in Subsection¬†11.2).

1.2 Plan of the Paper

In the next section we provide the relevant background material on CSPs and arithmetic constraints. The unifying tool in our analysis is integer interval arithmetic that is modeled after the real interval arithmetic (see, e.g., [15]). There are, however, essential differences since we deal with integers instead of reals. For example, the product of two integer intervals does not need to be an integer interval. In Section 3 we introduce integer interval arithmetic and establish the basic results. Then in Section 4 we show that using integer interval arithmetic we can define succinctly the well-known constraint propagation for linear constraints on integer intervals.

The next three sections, 5, 6 and 7, form the main part of the paper. We introduce there three approaches to constraint propagation for arithmetic constraints on integer intervals. They differ in the way the constraints are treated: either they are left intact, or the multiple occurrences of variables are eliminated, or the constraints are decomposed into a set of atomic constraints. In Section¬†8 we discuss how these three approaches relate to various methods used to solve arithmetic constraints on reals.

Then in Section 9 we characterize the effect of constraint propagation for the atomic constraints. In Section 10 we discuss in detail our implementation of the alternative approaches, and in Section¬†11 we describe the experiments that were performed to compare them. They indicate that decomposition of the constraints, combined with a scheduling of the reduction rules that respects the hierarchical dependencies between the atomic constraints is superior to the other approaches. Finally, in Section¬†12 we provide the conclusions.

The preliminary results of this work were reported in [2] and [3].

2 Preliminaries

2.1 Constraint Satisfaction Problems

We now review the standard concepts of a constraint and of a constraint satisfaction problem. Consider a sequence of variables X:=x1,‚Ä¶,xnassignùëãsubscriptùë•1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëõX:=x_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{n}italic_X := italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where n‚â•0ùëõ0n\geq 0italic_n ‚â• 0, with respective domains D1,‚Ä¶,Dnsubscriptùê∑1‚Ä¶subscriptùê∑ùëõD_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},D_{n}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT associated with them. So each variable xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ranges over the domain Disubscriptùê∑ùëñD_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. By a constraint Cùê∂Citalic_C on XùëãXitalic_X we mean a subset of D1√ó‚Ä¶√óDnsubscriptùê∑1‚Ä¶subscriptùê∑ùëõD_{1}\times\mbox{$\ldots$}\times D_{n}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT √ó ‚Ä¶ √ó italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Given an element d:=d1,‚Ä¶,dnassignùëësubscriptùëë1‚Ä¶subscriptùëëùëõd:=d_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},d_{n}italic_d := italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of D1√ó‚Ä¶√óDnsubscriptùê∑1‚Ä¶subscriptùê∑ùëõD_{1}\times\mbox{$\ldots$}\times D_{n}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT √ó ‚Ä¶ √ó italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and a subsequence Y:=xi1,‚Ä¶,xilassignùëåsubscriptùë•subscriptùëñ1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•subscriptùëñùëôY:=x_{i_{1}},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{i_{l}}italic_Y := italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of XùëãXitalic_X we denote by d‚Å¢[Y]ùëëdelimited-[]ùëåd[Y]italic_d [ italic_Y ] the sequence di1,‚Ä¶,dilsubscriptùëësubscriptùëñ1‚Ä¶subscriptùëësubscriptùëñùëôd_{i_{1}},\mbox{$\ldots$},d_{i_{l}}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In particular, for a variable xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from XùëãXitalic_X, d‚Å¢[xi]ùëëdelimited-[]subscriptùë•ùëñd[x_{i}]italic_d [ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] denotes disubscriptùëëùëñd_{i}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

A constraint satisfaction problem, in short CSP, consists of a finite sequence of variables XùëãXitalic_X with respective domains ùíüùíü{\cal D}caligraphic_D, together with a finite set ùíûùíû\cal Ccaligraphic_C of constraints, each on a subsequence of XùëãXitalic_X. We write it as ‚ü®ùíû;x1‚ààD1,‚Ä¶,xn‚ààDn‚ü©delimited-‚ü®‚ü©formulae-sequenceùíûsubscriptùë•1subscriptùê∑1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëõsubscriptùê∑ùëõ\langle{\cal C}\ ;\ x_{1}\in D_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{n}\in D_{n}\rangle‚ü® caligraphic_C ; italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ü©, where X:=x1,‚Ä¶,xnassignùëãsubscriptùë•1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëõX:=x_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{n}italic_X := italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ùíü:=D1,‚Ä¶,Dnassignùíüsubscriptùê∑1‚Ä¶subscriptùê∑ùëõ{\cal D}:=D_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},D_{n}caligraphic_D := italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

By a solution to ‚ü®ùíû;x1‚ààD1,‚Ä¶,xn‚ààDn‚ü©delimited-‚ü®‚ü©formulae-sequenceùíûsubscriptùë•1subscriptùê∑1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëõsubscriptùê∑ùëõ\langle{\cal C}\ ;\ x_{1}\in D_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{n}\in D_{n}\rangle‚ü® caligraphic_C ; italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ü© we mean an element d‚ààD1√ó‚Ä¶√óDnùëësubscriptùê∑1‚Ä¶subscriptùê∑ùëõd\in D_{1}\times\mbox{$\ldots$}\times D_{n}italic_d ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT √ó ‚Ä¶ √ó italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that for each constraint C‚ààùíûùê∂ùíûC\in{\cal C}italic_C ‚àà caligraphic_C on a sequence of variables XùëãXitalic_X we have d‚Å¢[X]‚ààCùëëdelimited-[]ùëãùê∂d[X]\in Citalic_d [ italic_X ] ‚àà italic_C. We call a CSP consistent if it has a solution and inconsistent if it does not. Two CSPs with the same sequence of variables are called equivalent if they have the same set of solutions. In what follows we consider CSPs whose constraints are defined in a simple language and when reasoning about them we identify the syntactic description of a constraint with its meaning being the set of tuples that satisfy it.

We view constraint propagation as a process of transforming CSPs that maintains their equivalence. In what follows we define this process by means of proof rules that operate on CSPs and preserve equivalence. An interested reader can consult [1] or [2] for a precise explanation of this approach to describing constraint propagation.

2.2 Arithmetic Constraints

To define the arithmetic constraints we use the alphabet that comprises

  • ‚Ä¢

    variables,

  • ‚Ä¢

    two constants, 0 and 1,

  • ‚Ä¢

    the unary minus function symbol ‚Äò‚àí--‚Äô,

  • ‚Ä¢

    three binary function symbols, ‚Äò+‚Äô,‚Äò‚àí--‚Äôand ‚Äò‚ãÖ‚ãÖ\cdot‚ãÖ‚Äô, all written in the infix notation.

By an arithmetic expression we mean a term formed in this alphabet and by an arithmetic constraint a formula of the form

s‚Å¢o‚Å¢p‚Å¢t,ùë†ùëúùëùùë°s\>op\>t,italic_s italic_o italic_p italic_t ,

where sùë†sitalic_s and tùë°titalic_t are arithmetic expressions and o‚Å¢p‚àà{<,‚â§,=,‚â†,‚â•,>}ùëúùëùop\in\mbox{$\{{<,\leq,=,\neq,\geq,>}\}$}italic_o italic_p ‚àà { < , ‚â§ , = , ‚â† , ‚â• , > }. For example

x5‚ãÖy2‚ãÖz4+3‚Å¢x‚ãÖy3‚ãÖz5‚â§10+4‚Å¢x4‚ãÖy6‚ãÖz2‚àíy2‚ãÖx5‚ãÖz4‚ãÖsuperscriptùë•5superscriptùë¶2superscriptùëß4‚ãÖ3ùë•superscriptùë¶3superscriptùëß510‚ãÖ4superscriptùë•4superscriptùë¶6superscriptùëß2‚ãÖsuperscriptùë¶2superscriptùë•5superscriptùëß4x^{5}\cdot y^{2}\cdot z^{4}+3x\cdot y^{3}\cdot z^{5}\leq 10+4x^{4}\cdot y^{6}\cdot z^{2}-y^{2}\cdot x^{5}\cdot z^{4}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 3 italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚â§ 10 + 4 italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 6 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (1)

is an arithmetic constraint. Here x5superscriptùë•5x^{5}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is an abbreviation for x‚ãÖx‚ãÖx‚ãÖx‚ãÖx‚ãÖùë•ùë•ùë•ùë•ùë•x\cdot x\cdot x\cdot x\cdot xitalic_x ‚ãÖ italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_x, while 3‚Å¢x‚ãÖy3‚ãÖz5‚ãÖ3ùë•superscriptùë¶3superscriptùëß53x\cdot y^{3}\cdot z^{5}3 italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is an abbreviation for x‚ãÖy3‚ãÖz5+x‚ãÖy3‚ãÖz5+x‚ãÖy3‚ãÖz5‚ãÖùë•superscriptùë¶3superscriptùëß5‚ãÖùë•superscriptùë¶3superscriptùëß5‚ãÖùë•superscriptùë¶3superscriptùëß5x\cdot y^{3}\cdot z^{5}+x\cdot y^{3}\cdot z^{5}+x\cdot y^{3}\cdot z^{5}italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and similarly with the other expressions. If ‚Äò‚ãÖ‚ãÖ\cdot‚ãÖ‚Äô is not used in an arithmetic constraint, we call it a linear constraint.

By an extended arithmetic expression we mean a term formed in the above alphabet extended by the unary function symbols ‚Äò‚ãÖnsuperscript‚ãÖùëõ\cdot^{n}‚ãÖ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT‚Äô and ‚Äò‚ãÖnùëõ‚ãÖ\sqrt[n]{\cdot}nth-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG ‚ãÖ end_ARG‚Äô for each n‚â•1ùëõ1n\geq 1italic_n ‚â• 1 and the binary function symbol ‚Äò///‚Äô written in the infix notation. For example

(y2‚ãÖz4)/(x2‚ãÖu5)33‚ãÖsuperscriptùë¶2superscriptùëß4‚ãÖsuperscriptùë•2superscriptùë¢5\sqrt[3]{(y^{2}\cdot z^{4})/(x^{2}\cdot u^{5})}nth-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG ( italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) / ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG (2)

is an extended arithmetic expression. Here, unlike in (1), x5superscriptùë•5x^{5}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a term obtained by applying the function symbol ‚Äò‚ãÖ5superscript‚ãÖ5\cdot^{5}‚ãÖ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT‚Äô to the variable xùë•xitalic_x. The extended arithmetic expressions will be used only to define constraint propagation for the arithmetic constraints.

Fix now some arbitrary linear ordering ‚â∫precedes\prec‚â∫ on the variables of the language. By a monomial we mean an integer or a term of the form

a‚ãÖx1n1‚ãÖ‚Ä¶‚ãÖxknk‚ãÖùëésuperscriptsubscriptùë•1subscriptùëõ1‚Ä¶superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëòsubscriptùëõùëòa\cdot x_{1}^{n_{1}}\cdot\mbox{$\ldots$}\cdot x_{k}^{n_{k}}italic_a ‚ãÖ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ ‚Ä¶ ‚ãÖ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT

where k>0ùëò0k>0italic_k > 0, x1,‚Ä¶,xksubscriptùë•1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëòx_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{k}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are different variables ordered w.r.t.¬†‚â∫precedes\prec‚â∫, and aùëéaitalic_a is a non-zero integer and n1,‚Ä¶,nksubscriptùëõ1‚Ä¶subscriptùëõùëòn_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},n_{k}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are positive integers. We call then x1n1‚ãÖ‚Ä¶‚ãÖxknk‚ãÖsuperscriptsubscriptùë•1subscriptùëõ1‚Ä¶superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëòsubscriptùëõùëòx_{1}^{n_{1}}\cdot\mbox{$\ldots$}\cdot x_{k}^{n_{k}}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ ‚Ä¶ ‚ãÖ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT the power product of this monomial.

Next, by a polynomial we mean a term of the form

Œ£i=1n‚Å¢mi,subscriptsuperscriptŒ£ùëõùëñ1subscriptùëöùëñ\Sigma^{n}_{i=1}m_{i},roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

where n>0ùëõ0n>0italic_n > 0, at most one monomial misubscriptùëöùëñm_{i}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is an integer, and the power products of the monomials m1,‚Ä¶,mnsubscriptùëö1‚Ä¶subscriptùëöùëõm_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},m_{n}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are pairwise different. Finally, by a polynomial constraint we mean an arithmetic constraint of the form s‚Å¢o‚Å¢p‚Å¢bùë†ùëúùëùùëès\>op\>bitalic_s italic_o italic_p italic_b, where sùë†sitalic_s is a polynomial with no monomial being an integer, o‚Å¢p‚àà{<,‚â§,=,‚â†,‚â•,>}ùëúùëùop\in\mbox{$\{{<,\leq,=,\neq,\geq,>}\}$}italic_o italic_p ‚àà { < , ‚â§ , = , ‚â† , ‚â• , > }, and bùëèbitalic_b is an integer. It is clear that by means of appropriate transformation rules we can transform each arithmetic constraint to a polynomial constraint. For example, assuming the ordering x‚â∫y‚â∫zprecedesùë•ùë¶precedesùëßx\prec y\prec zitalic_x ‚â∫ italic_y ‚â∫ italic_z on the variables, the arithmetic constraint (1) can be transformed to the polynomial constraint

2‚Å¢x5‚ãÖy2‚ãÖz4‚àí4‚Å¢x4‚ãÖy6‚ãÖz2+3‚Å¢x‚ãÖy3‚ãÖz5‚â§10‚ãÖ2superscriptùë•5superscriptùë¶2superscriptùëß4‚ãÖ4superscriptùë•4superscriptùë¶6superscriptùëß2‚ãÖ3ùë•superscriptùë¶3superscriptùëß5102x^{5}\cdot y^{2}\cdot z^{4}-4x^{4}\cdot y^{6}\cdot z^{2}+3x\cdot y^{3}\cdot z^{5}\leq 102 italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 4 italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 6 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 3 italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚â§ 10

So, without loss of generality, from now on we shall limit our attention to polynomial constraints.

Next, let us discuss the domains over which we interpret the arithmetic constraints. By an integer interval, or an interval in short, we mean an expression of the form

[a..b][a..b][ italic_a . . italic_b ]

where aùëéaitalic_a and bùëèbitalic_b are integers; [a..b][a..b][ italic_a . . italic_b ] denotes the set of all integers between aùëéaitalic_a and bùëèbitalic_b, including aùëéaitalic_a and bùëèbitalic_b. If a>bùëéùëèa>bitalic_a > italic_b, we call [a..b][a..b][ italic_a . . italic_b ] the empty interval and denote it by ‚àÖ\emptyset‚àÖ. By a range we mean an expression of the form

x‚ààIùë•ùêºx\in Iitalic_x ‚àà italic_I

where xùë•xitalic_x is a variable and IùêºIitalic_I is an interval. Sets of the form {x‚ààùíµ|x‚â•a}conditional-setùë•ùíµùë•ùëé\{x\in\mathcal{Z}|x\geq a\}{ italic_x ‚àà caligraphic_Z | italic_x ‚â• italic_a } and {x‚ààùíµ|x‚â§b}conditional-setùë•ùíµùë•ùëè\{x\in\mathcal{Z}|x\leq b\}{ italic_x ‚àà caligraphic_Z | italic_x ‚â§ italic_b } are called extended intervals.

We link the arithmetic constraints with the notion of a constraint defined in the previous section by associating in the standard way with each arithmetic constraint its interpretation. For an arithmetic constraint on variables x1,‚Ä¶,xnsubscriptùë•1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëõx_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{n}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with respective integer interval domains D1,‚Ä¶,Dnsubscriptùê∑1‚Ä¶subscriptùê∑ùëõD_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},D_{n}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT this is a subset of D1√ó‚Ä¶√óDnsubscriptùê∑1‚Ä¶subscriptùê∑ùëõD_{1}\times\mbox{$\ldots$}\times D_{n}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT √ó ‚Ä¶ √ó italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

3 Integer Set Arithmetic

To reason about the arithmetic constraints we employ a generalization of the arithmetic operations to the sets of integers. Here and elsewhere ùíµùíµ{\cal Z}caligraphic_Z, ùí©ùí©{\cal N}caligraphic_N, and ‚Ñõ‚Ñõ{\cal R}caligraphic_R denote the sets of all integers, natural numbers, and reals, respectively.

3.1 Definitions

For X,YùëãùëåX,Yitalic_X , italic_Y sets of integers we define the following operations:

  • ‚Ä¢

    addition:

    X+Y:={x+y‚à£x‚ààX,y‚ààY},assignùëãùëåconditional-setùë•ùë¶formulae-sequenceùë•ùëãùë¶ùëåX+Y:=\mbox{$\{{x+y\mid x\in X,y\in Y}\}$},italic_X + italic_Y := { italic_x + italic_y ‚à£ italic_x ‚àà italic_X , italic_y ‚àà italic_Y } ,
  • ‚Ä¢

    subtraction:

    X‚àíY:={x‚àíy‚à£x‚ààX,y‚ààY},assignùëãùëåconditional-setùë•ùë¶formulae-sequenceùë•ùëãùë¶ùëåX-Y:=\mbox{$\{{x-y\mid x\in X,y\in Y}\}$},italic_X - italic_Y := { italic_x - italic_y ‚à£ italic_x ‚àà italic_X , italic_y ‚àà italic_Y } ,
  • ‚Ä¢

    multiplication:

    X‚ãÖY:={x‚ãÖy‚à£x‚ààX,y‚ààY},assign‚ãÖùëãùëåconditional-set‚ãÖùë•ùë¶formulae-sequenceùë•ùëãùë¶ùëåX\cdot Y:=\mbox{$\{{x\cdot y\mid x\in X,y\in Y}\}$},italic_X ‚ãÖ italic_Y := { italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y ‚à£ italic_x ‚àà italic_X , italic_y ‚àà italic_Y } ,
  • ‚Ä¢

    division:

    X/Y:={u‚ààùíµ‚à£‚àÉx‚ààX‚Å¢‚àÉy‚ààY‚Å¢u‚ãÖy=x},assignùëãùëåconditional-setùë¢ùíµùë•ùëãùë¶‚ãÖùëåùë¢ùë¶ùë•X/Y:=\mbox{$\{{u\in{\cal Z}\mid\mbox{$\exists$}x\in X\mbox{$\exists$}y\in Y\>u\cdot y=x}\}$},italic_X / italic_Y := { italic_u ‚àà caligraphic_Z ‚à£ ‚àÉ italic_x ‚àà italic_X ‚àÉ italic_y ‚àà italic_Y italic_u ‚ãÖ italic_y = italic_x } ,
  • ‚Ä¢

    exponentiation:

    Xn:={xn‚à£x‚ààX},assignsuperscriptùëãùëõconditional-setsuperscriptùë•ùëõùë•ùëãX^{n}:=\mbox{$\{{x^{n}\mid x\in X}\}$},italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := { italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à£ italic_x ‚àà italic_X } ,

    for each natural number n>0ùëõ0n>0italic_n > 0,

  • ‚Ä¢

    root extraction:

    Xn:={x‚ààùíµ‚à£xn‚ààX},assignùëõùëãconditional-setùë•ùíµsuperscriptùë•ùëõùëã\sqrt[n]{X}:=\mbox{$\{{x\in{\cal Z}\mid x^{n}\in X}\}$},nth-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG italic_X end_ARG := { italic_x ‚àà caligraphic_Z ‚à£ italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àà italic_X } ,

    for each natural number n>0ùëõ0n>0italic_n > 0.

All the operations except division and root extraction are defined in the expected way. We shall return to the division operation in Section¬†7. At the moment it suffices to note the division operation is defined for all sets of integers, including Y=‚àÖùëåY=\mbox{$\emptyset$}italic_Y = ‚àÖ and Y={0}ùëå0Y=\mbox{$\{{0}\}$}italic_Y = { 0 }. This division operation corresponds to the following division operation on the sets of reals introduced in [18]:

X‚äòY:={u‚àà‚Ñõ‚à£‚àÉx‚ààX‚Å¢‚àÉy‚ààY‚Å¢u‚ãÖy=x}.assign‚äòùëãùëåconditional-setùë¢‚Ñõùë•ùëãùë¶‚ãÖùëåùë¢ùë¶ùë•X\oslash Y:=\mbox{$\{{u\in{\cal R}\mid\mbox{$\exists$}x\in X\mbox{$\exists$}y\in Y\>u\cdot y=x}\}$}.italic_X ‚äò italic_Y := { italic_u ‚àà caligraphic_R ‚à£ ‚àÉ italic_x ‚àà italic_X ‚àÉ italic_y ‚àà italic_Y italic_u ‚ãÖ italic_y = italic_x } .

For an integer or real number aùëéaitalic_a and o‚Å¢p‚àà{+,‚àí,‚ãÖ,/,‚äò}ùëúùëù‚ãÖ‚äòop\in\mbox{$\{{+,-,\cdot,/,\oslash}\}$}italic_o italic_p ‚àà { + , - , ‚ãÖ , / , ‚äò } we identify a‚Å¢o‚Å¢p‚Å¢Xùëéùëúùëùùëãa\>op\>Xitalic_a italic_o italic_p italic_X with {a}‚Å¢o‚Å¢p‚Å¢Xùëéùëúùëùùëã\mbox{$\{{a}\}$}\>op\>X{ italic_a } italic_o italic_p italic_X and X‚Å¢o‚Å¢p‚Å¢aùëãùëúùëùùëéX\>op\>aitalic_X italic_o italic_p italic_a with X‚Å¢o‚Å¢p‚Å¢{a}ùëãùëúùëùùëéX\>op\>\mbox{$\{{a}\}$}italic_X italic_o italic_p { italic_a }.

To present the rules we are interested in we shall also use the addition and division operations on the sets of reals. Addition is defined in the same way as for the sets of integers, and for division we use the ‚äò‚äò\oslash‚äò operator defined above. In [15] it is explained how to implement these operations on, possibly unbounded, real intervals.

Further, given a set Aùê¥Aitalic_A of integers or reals, we define

A‚â§:={x‚ààùíµ‚à£‚àÉa‚ààA‚Å¢x‚â§a},assignsuperscriptùê¥conditional-setùë•ùíµùëéùê¥ùë•ùëé{}^{\leq}A:=\mbox{$\{{x\in{\cal Z}\mid\mbox{$\exists$}a\in A\>x\leq a}\}$},start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT ‚â§ end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT italic_A := { italic_x ‚àà caligraphic_Z ‚à£ ‚àÉ italic_a ‚àà italic_A italic_x ‚â§ italic_a } ,
A‚â•:={x‚ààùíµ‚à£‚àÉa‚ààA‚Å¢x‚â•a},assignsuperscriptùê¥conditional-setùë•ùíµùëéùê¥ùë•ùëé{}^{\geq}A:=\mbox{$\{{x\in{\cal Z}\mid\mbox{$\exists$}a\in A\>x\geq a}\}$},start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT ‚â• end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT italic_A := { italic_x ‚àà caligraphic_Z ‚à£ ‚àÉ italic_a ‚àà italic_A italic_x ‚â• italic_a } ,

so for example ùí©‚â§=ùíµsuperscriptùí©ùíµ{}^{\leq}{\mathcal{N}}=\mathcal{Z}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT ‚â§ end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_N = caligraphic_Z, and {‚àí1,1}‚â•{}^{\geq}\{-1,1\}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT ‚â• end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT { - 1 , 1 } and (‚àí2,2)‚â•{}^{\geq}(-2,2)start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT ‚â• end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT ( - 2 , 2 ) both denote the extended interval of all integers greater than or equal to ‚àí11-1- 1, where (‚àí2,2)22(-2,2)( - 2 , 2 ) denotes an open interval of real numbers.

When limiting our attention to intervals of integers the following simple observation is of importance.

Note 3.1

For X,YùëãùëåX,Yitalic_X , italic_Y integer intervals and aùëéaitalic_a an integer the following holds:

  • ‚Ä¢

    X‚à©YùëãùëåX\cap Yitalic_X ‚à© italic_Y, X+Y,X‚àíYùëãùëåùëãùëåX+Y,X-Yitalic_X + italic_Y , italic_X - italic_Y are integer intervals.

  • ‚Ä¢

    X/{a}ùëãùëéX/\mbox{$\{{a}\}$}italic_X / { italic_a } is an integer interval.

  • ‚Ä¢

    X‚ãÖY‚ãÖùëãùëåX\cdot Yitalic_X ‚ãÖ italic_Y does not have to be an integer interval, even if X={a}ùëãùëéX=\mbox{$\{{a}\}$}italic_X = { italic_a } or Y={a}ùëåùëéY=\mbox{$\{{a}\}$}italic_Y = { italic_a }.

  • ‚Ä¢

    X/YùëãùëåX/Yitalic_X / italic_Y does not have to be an integer interval.

  • ‚Ä¢

    For each n>1ùëõ1n>1italic_n > 1, ¬†XnsuperscriptùëãùëõX^{n}italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT does not have to be an integer interval.

  • ‚Ä¢

    For odd n>1ùëõ1n>1italic_n > 1, ¬†Xnùëõùëã\sqrt[n]{X}nth-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG italic_X end_ARG is an integer interval.

  • ‚Ä¢

    For even n>1ùëõ1n>1italic_n > 1, ¬†Xnùëõùëã\sqrt[n]{X}nth-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG italic_X end_ARG is an integer interval or a disjoint union of two integer intervals. ‚ñ°‚ñ°\Box‚ñ°

For example in the following cases we get intervals as outcomes:

[2..4]+[3..8]=[5..12],delimited-[]2..4delimited-[]3..8delimited-[]5..12[2..4]+[3..8]=[5..12],[ 2..4 ] + [ 3..8 ] = [ 5..12 ] ,
[3..7]‚àí[1..8]=[‚àí5..6],delimited-[]3..7delimited-[]1..8delimited-[]5..6[3..7]-[1..8]=[-5..6],[ 3..7 ] - [ 1..8 ] = [ - 5..6 ] ,
[‚àí30..100]3=[‚àí3..4],3delimited-[]30..100delimited-[]3..4\sqrt[3]{[-30..100]}=[-3..4],nth-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG [ - 30..100 ] end_ARG = [ - 3..4 ] ,
[‚àí100..9]2=[‚àí3..3],2delimited-[]100..9delimited-[]3..3\sqrt[2]{[-100..9]}=[-3..3],nth-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG [ - 100..9 ] end_ARG = [ - 3..3 ] ,

while in the following ones not:

[3..3]‚ãÖ[1..2]={3,6},‚ãÖdelimited-[]3..3delimited-[]1..236[3..3]\cdot[1..2]=\mbox{$\{{3,6}\}$},[ 3..3 ] ‚ãÖ [ 1..2 ] = { 3 , 6 } ,
[3..5]/[‚àí1..2]={‚àí5,‚àí4,‚àí3,2,3,4,5},delimited-[]3..5delimited-[]1..25432345[3..5]/[-1..2]=\mbox{$\{{-5,-4,-3,2,3,4,5}\}$},[ 3..5 ] / [ - 1..2 ] = { - 5 , - 4 , - 3 , 2 , 3 , 4 , 5 } ,
[‚àí3..5]/[‚àí1..2]=ùíµ,delimited-[]3..5delimited-[]1..2ùíµ[-3..5]/[-1..2]={\cal Z},[ - 3..5 ] / [ - 1..2 ] = caligraphic_Z ,
[1..2]2={1,4},superscriptdelimited-[]1..2214[1..2]^{2}=\mbox{$\{{1,4}\}$},[ 1..2 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = { 1 , 4 } ,
[1..9]2=[‚àí3..‚àí1]‚à™[1..3].\sqrt[2]{[1..9]}=[-3..-1]\cup[1..3].nth-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG [ 1..9 ] end_ARG = [ - 3 . . - 1 ] ‚à™ [ 1..3 ] .

To deal with the problem that non-interval domains can be produced by some of the operations we introduce the following operation on the sets of integers:

int(X):={smallest integer interval containing¬†Xif¬†X¬†is finite,ùíµotherwise.\operatorname{int}(X):=\left\{\begin{tabular}[]{ll}\mbox{smallest integer interval containing $X$}&\mbox{if $X$ is finite,}\\ ${\cal Z}$&\mbox{otherwise.}\end{tabular}\right.roman_int ( italic_X ) := { start_ROW start_CELL smallest integer interval containing X end_CELL start_CELL if X is finite, end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL caligraphic_Z end_CELL start_CELL otherwise. end_CELL end_ROW

For example int‚Å°([3..5]/[‚àí1..2])=[‚àí5..5]intdelimited-[]3..5delimited-[]1..2delimited-[]5..5\operatorname{int}([3..5]/[-1..2])=[-5..5]roman_int ( [ 3..5 ] / [ - 1..2 ] ) = [ - 5..5 ] and int‚Å°([‚àí3..5]/[‚àí1..2])=ùíµintdelimited-[]3..5delimited-[]1..2ùíµ\operatorname{int}([-3..5]/[-1..2])={\cal Z}roman_int ( [ - 3..5 ] / [ - 1..2 ] ) = caligraphic_Z.

3.2 Implementation

To define constraint propagation for the arithmetic constraints on integer intervals we shall use the integer set arithmetic, mainly limited to the integer intervals. This brings us to the discussion of how to implement the introduced operations on the integer intervals. Since we are only interested in maintaining the property that the sets remain integer intervals or the set of integers ùíµùíµ{\cal Z}caligraphic_Z we shall clarify how to implement the intersection, addition, subtraction and root extraction operations of the integer intervals and the int‚Å°(‚ãÖ)int‚ãÖ\operatorname{int}(\cdot)roman_int ( ‚ãÖ ) closure of the multiplication, division and exponentiation operations on the integer intervals. The case when one of the intervals is empty is easy to deal with. So we assume that we deal with non-empty intervals [a..b][a..b][ italic_a . . italic_b ] and [c..d][c..d][ italic_c . . italic_d ], that is a‚â§bùëéùëèa\leq bitalic_a ‚â§ italic_b and c‚â§dùëêùëëc\leq ditalic_c ‚â§ italic_d.

Intersection, addition and subtraction

It is easy to see that

[a..b]‚à©[c..d]=[max(a,c)..min(b,d)],[a..b]\cap[c..d]=[\operatorname{max}(a,c)..\operatorname{min}(b,d)],[ italic_a . . italic_b ] ‚à© [ italic_c . . italic_d ] = [ roman_max ( italic_a , italic_c ) . . roman_min ( italic_b , italic_d ) ] ,
[a..b]+[c..d]=[a+c..b+d],[a..b]+[c..d]=[a+c\ ..\ b+d],[ italic_a . . italic_b ] + [ italic_c . . italic_d ] = [ italic_a + italic_c . . italic_b + italic_d ] ,
[a..b]‚àí[c..d]=[a‚àíd..b‚àíc].[a..b]-[c..d]=[a-d\ ..\ b-c].[ italic_a . . italic_b ] - [ italic_c . . italic_d ] = [ italic_a - italic_d . . italic_b - italic_c ] .

So the interval intersection, addition, and subtraction are straightforward to implement.

Root extraction

The outcome of the root extraction operator applied to an integer interval will be an integer interval or a disjoint union of two integer intervals. We shall explain in Section 5 why it is advantageous not to apply int‚Å°(‚ãÖ)int‚ãÖ\operatorname{int}(\cdot)roman_int ( ‚ãÖ ) to the outcome. This operator can be implemented by means of the following case analysis.

Case 1. Suppose nùëõnitalic_n is odd. Then

[a..b]n=[‚åàan‚åâ..‚åäbn‚åã].\sqrt[n]{[a..b]}=[\left\lceil\sqrt[n]{a}\right\rceil..\left\lfloor\sqrt[n]{b}\right\rfloor].nth-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG [ italic_a . . italic_b ] end_ARG = [ ‚åà nth-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG italic_a end_ARG ‚åâ . . ‚åä nth-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG italic_b end_ARG ‚åã ] .

Case 2. Suppose nùëõnitalic_n is even and b<0ùëè0b<0italic_b < 0. Then

[a..b]n=‚àÖ.\sqrt[n]{[a..b]}=\mbox{$\emptyset$}.nth-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG [ italic_a . . italic_b ] end_ARG = ‚àÖ .

Case 3. Suppose nùëõnitalic_n is even and b‚â•0ùëè0b\geq 0italic_b ‚â• 0. Then

[a..b]n=[‚àí‚åä|bn|‚åã..‚àí‚åà|a+n|‚åâ]‚à™[‚åà|a+n|‚åâ..‚åä|bn|‚åã]\sqrt[n]{[a..b]}=[-\left\lfloor|\sqrt[n]{b}|\right\rfloor..-\left\lceil|\sqrt[n]{a_{+}}|\right\rceil]\cup[\left\lceil|\sqrt[n]{a_{+}}|\right\rceil..\left\lfloor|\sqrt[n]{b}|\right\rfloor]nth-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG [ italic_a . . italic_b ] end_ARG = [ - ‚åä | nth-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG italic_b end_ARG | ‚åã . . - ‚åà | nth-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | ‚åâ ] ‚à™ [ ‚åà | nth-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | ‚åâ . . ‚åä | nth-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG italic_b end_ARG | ‚åã ]

where a+:=max‚Å°(0,a)assignsubscriptùëémax0ùëéa_{+}:=\operatorname{max}(0,a)italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := roman_max ( 0 , italic_a ).

Multiplication

For the remaining operations we only need to explain how to implement the int‚Å°(‚ãÖ)int‚ãÖ\operatorname{int}(\cdot)roman_int ( ‚ãÖ ) closure of the outcome. First note that

int([a..b]‚ãÖ[c..d])=[min(A)..max(A)],\operatorname{int}([a..b]\cdot[c..d])=[\operatorname{min}(A)..\operatorname{max}(A)],roman_int ( [ italic_a . . italic_b ] ‚ãÖ [ italic_c . . italic_d ] ) = [ roman_min ( italic_A ) . . roman_max ( italic_A ) ] ,

where A={a‚ãÖc,a‚ãÖd,b‚ãÖc,b‚ãÖd}ùê¥‚ãÖùëéùëê‚ãÖùëéùëë‚ãÖùëèùëê‚ãÖùëèùëëA=\mbox{$\{{a\cdot c,a\cdot d,b\cdot c,b\cdot d}\}$}italic_A = { italic_a ‚ãÖ italic_c , italic_a ‚ãÖ italic_d , italic_b ‚ãÖ italic_c , italic_b ‚ãÖ italic_d }.

Using an appropriate case analysis we can actually compute the bounds of int([a..b]‚ãÖ[c..d])\operatorname{int}([a..b]\cdot[c..d])roman_int ( [ italic_a . . italic_b ] ‚ãÖ [ italic_c . . italic_d ] ) directly in terms of the bounds of the constituent intervals.

Division

In contrast, the int‚Å°(‚ãÖ)int‚ãÖ\operatorname{int}(\cdot)roman_int ( ‚ãÖ ) closure of the interval division is not so straightforward to compute. The reason is that, as we shall see in a moment, we cannot express the result in terms of some simple operations on the interval bounds.

Consider non-empty integer intervals [a..b][a..b][ italic_a . . italic_b ] and [c..d][c..d][ italic_c . . italic_d ]. In analyzing the outcome of int([a..b]/[c..d])\operatorname{int}([a..b]/[c..d])roman_int ( [ italic_a . . italic_b ] / [ italic_c . . italic_d ] ) we distinguish the following cases.

Case 1. Suppose 0‚àà[a..b]0\in[a..b]0 ‚àà [ italic_a . . italic_b ] and 0‚àà[c..d]0\in[c..d]0 ‚àà [ italic_c . . italic_d ].

Then by definition int([a..b]/[c..d])=ùíµ\operatorname{int}([a..b]/[c..d])={\cal Z}roman_int ( [ italic_a . . italic_b ] / [ italic_c . . italic_d ] ) = caligraphic_Z. For example,

int‚Å°([‚àí1..100]/[‚àí2..8])=ùíµ.intdelimited-[]1..100delimited-[]2..8ùíµ\operatorname{int}([-1..100]/[-2..8])={\cal Z}.roman_int ( [ - 1..100 ] / [ - 2..8 ] ) = caligraphic_Z .

Case 2. Suppose 0‚àâ[a..b]0\not\in[a..b]0 ‚àâ [ italic_a . . italic_b ] and c=d=0ùëêùëë0c=d=0italic_c = italic_d = 0.

Then by definition int([a..b]/[c..d])=‚àÖ\operatorname{int}([a..b]/[c..d])=\mbox{$\emptyset$}roman_int ( [ italic_a . . italic_b ] / [ italic_c . . italic_d ] ) = ‚àÖ. For example,

int‚Å°([10..100]/[0..0])=‚àÖ.intdelimited-[]10..100delimited-[]0..0\operatorname{int}([10..100]/[0..0])=\mbox{$\emptyset$}.roman_int ( [ 10..100 ] / [ 0..0 ] ) = ‚àÖ .

Case 3. Suppose 0‚àâ[a..b]0\not\in[a..b]0 ‚àâ [ italic_a . . italic_b ] and c<0ùëê0c<0italic_c < 0 and 0<d0ùëë0<d0 < italic_d.

It is easy to see that then

int([a..b]/[c..d])=[‚àíe..e],\operatorname{int}([a..b]/[c..d])=[-e..e],roman_int ( [ italic_a . . italic_b ] / [ italic_c . . italic_d ] ) = [ - italic_e . . italic_e ] ,

where e=max‚Å°(|a|,|b|)ùëímaxùëéùëèe=\operatorname{max}(|a|,|b|)italic_e = roman_max ( | italic_a | , | italic_b | ). For example,

int([‚àí100..‚àí10]/[‚àí2..5])=[‚àí100..100].\operatorname{int}([-100..-10]/[-2..5])=[-100..100].roman_int ( [ - 100 . . - 10 ] / [ - 2..5 ] ) = [ - 100..100 ] .

Case 4. Suppose 0‚àâ[a..b]0\not\in[a..b]0 ‚àâ [ italic_a . . italic_b ] and either c=0ùëê0c=0italic_c = 0 and d‚â†0ùëë0d\neq 0italic_d ‚â† 0 or c‚â†0ùëê0c\neq 0italic_c ‚â† 0 and d=0ùëë0d=0italic_d = 0.

Then int([a..b]/[c..d])=int([a..b]/([c..d]‚àí{0}))\operatorname{int}([a..b]/[c..d])=\operatorname{int}([a..b]/([c..d]-\mbox{$\{{0}\}$}))roman_int ( [ italic_a . . italic_b ] / [ italic_c . . italic_d ] ) = roman_int ( [ italic_a . . italic_b ] / ( [ italic_c . . italic_d ] - { 0 } ) ). For example

int([1..100]/[‚àí7..0])=int([1..100]/[‚àí7..‚àí1]).\operatorname{int}([1..100]/[-7..0])=\operatorname{int}([1..100]/[-7..-1]).roman_int ( [ 1..100 ] / [ - 7..0 ] ) = roman_int ( [ 1..100 ] / [ - 7 . . - 1 ] ) .

This allows us to reduce this case to Case 5 below.

Case 5. Suppose 0‚àâ[c..d]0\not\in[c..d]0 ‚àâ [ italic_c . . italic_d ].

This is the only case when we need to compute int([a..b]/[c..d])\operatorname{int}([a..b]/[c..d])roman_int ( [ italic_a . . italic_b ] / [ italic_c . . italic_d ] ) indirectly. First, observe that we have

int([a..b]/[c..d])‚äÜ[‚åàmin(A)‚åâ..‚åämax(A)‚åã],\operatorname{int}([a..b]/[c..d])\mbox{$\>\subseteq\>$}[\left\lceil\operatorname{min}(A)\right\rceil..\left\lfloor\operatorname{max}(A)\right\rfloor],roman_int ( [ italic_a . . italic_b ] / [ italic_c . . italic_d ] ) ‚äÜ [ ‚åà roman_min ( italic_A ) ‚åâ . . ‚åä roman_max ( italic_A ) ‚åã ] ,

where A={a/c,a/d,b/c,b/d}ùê¥ùëéùëêùëéùëëùëèùëêùëèùëëA=\mbox{$\{{a/c,a/d,b/c,b/d}\}$}italic_A = { italic_a / italic_c , italic_a / italic_d , italic_b / italic_c , italic_b / italic_d }.

However, the equality does not need to hold here. Indeed, note for example that int‚Å°([155..161]/[9..11])=[16..16]intdelimited-[]155..161delimited-[]9..11delimited-[]16..16\operatorname{int}([155..161]/[9..11])=[16..16]roman_int ( [ 155..161 ] / [ 9..11 ] ) = [ 16..16 ], whereas for A={155/9,155/11,161/9A=\{155/9,155/11,161/9italic_A = { 155 / 9 , 155 / 11 , 161 / 9, 161/11}161/11\}161 / 11 } we have ‚åàmin‚Å°(A)‚åâ=15minùê¥15\left\lceil\operatorname{min}(A)\right\rceil=15‚åà roman_min ( italic_A ) ‚åâ = 15 and ‚åämax‚Å°(A)‚åã=17maxùê¥17\left\lfloor\operatorname{max}(A)\right\rfloor=17‚åä roman_max ( italic_A ) ‚åã = 17. The problem is that the value 16 is obtained by dividing 160 by 10 and none of these two values is an interval bound.

This complication can be solved by preprocessing the interval [c..d][c..d][ italic_c . . italic_d ] so that its bounds are actual divisors of an element of [a..b][a..b][ italic_a . . italic_b ]. First, we look for the least c‚Ä≤‚àà[c..d]c^{\prime}\in[c..d]italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àà [ italic_c . . italic_d ] such that ‚àÉx‚àà[a..b]‚àÉu‚ààùíµu‚ãÖc‚Ä≤=x\exists x\in[a..b]\ \exists u\in{\cal Z}\ u\cdot c^{\prime}=x‚àÉ italic_x ‚àà [ italic_a . . italic_b ] ‚àÉ italic_u ‚àà caligraphic_Z italic_u ‚ãÖ italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_x. Using a case analysis, the latter property can be established without search. Suppose for example that a>0ùëé0a>0italic_a > 0 and c>0ùëê0c>0italic_c > 0. In this case, if c‚Ä≤‚ãÖ‚åäb/c‚Ä≤‚åã‚â•a‚ãÖsuperscriptùëê‚Ä≤ùëèsuperscriptùëê‚Ä≤ùëéc^{\prime}\cdot\lfloor b/c^{\prime}\rfloor\geq aitalic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ ‚åä italic_b / italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚åã ‚â• italic_a, then c‚Ä≤superscriptùëê‚Ä≤c^{\prime}italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has the required property. Similarly, we look for the largest d‚Ä≤‚àà[c..d]d^{\prime}\in[c..d]italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àà [ italic_c . . italic_d ] for which an analogous condition holds. Now int([a..b]/[c..d])=[‚åàmin(A)‚åâ..‚åämax(A)‚åã]\operatorname{int}([a..b]/[c..d])=[\lceil\operatorname{min}(A)\rceil..\lfloor\operatorname{max}(A)\rfloor]roman_int ( [ italic_a . . italic_b ] / [ italic_c . . italic_d ] ) = [ ‚åà roman_min ( italic_A ) ‚åâ . . ‚åä roman_max ( italic_A ) ‚åã ], where A={a/c‚Ä≤,a/d‚Ä≤,b/c‚Ä≤,b/d‚Ä≤}ùê¥ùëésuperscriptùëê‚Ä≤ùëésuperscriptùëë‚Ä≤ùëèsuperscriptùëê‚Ä≤ùëèsuperscriptùëë‚Ä≤A=\{a/c^{\prime},a/d^{\prime},b/c^{\prime},b/d^{\prime}\}italic_A = { italic_a / italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a / italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_b / italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_b / italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT }.

In view of this auxiliary computation (in case when 0‚àâ[c..d]0\not\in[c..d]0 ‚àâ [ italic_c . . italic_d ]) we shall introduce in Section 10 a modified division operation with a more direct implementation.

Exponentiation

The int‚Å°(‚ãÖ)int‚ãÖ\operatorname{int}(\cdot)roman_int ( ‚ãÖ ) closure of the interval exponentiation is straightforward to implement by distinguishing the following cases.

Case 1. Suppose nùëõnitalic_n is odd. Then

int([a..b]n)=[an..bn].\operatorname{int}([a..b]^{n})=[a^{n}..\>b^{n}].roman_int ( [ italic_a . . italic_b ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = [ italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . . italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] .

Case 2. Suppose nùëõnitalic_n is even and 0‚â§a0ùëé0\leq a0 ‚â§ italic_a. Then

int([a..b]n)=[an..bn].\operatorname{int}([a..b]^{n})=[a^{n}..\>b^{n}].roman_int ( [ italic_a . . italic_b ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = [ italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . . italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] .

Case 3. Suppose nùëõnitalic_n is even and b‚â§0ùëè0b\leq 0italic_b ‚â§ 0. Then

int([a..b]n)=[bn..an].\operatorname{int}([a..b]^{n})=[b^{n}..\>a^{n}].roman_int ( [ italic_a . . italic_b ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = [ italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . . italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] .

Case 4. Suppose nùëõnitalic_n is even and a<0ùëé0a<0italic_a < 0 and 0<b0ùëè0<b0 < italic_b. Then

int([a..b]n)=[0..max(an,bn)].\operatorname{int}([a..b]^{n})=[0..\operatorname{max}(a^{n},b^{n})].roman_int ( [ italic_a . . italic_b ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = [ 0 . . roman_max ( italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] .

3.3 Correctness Lemma

Given now an extended arithmetic expression sùë†sitalic_s each variable of which ranges over an integer interval, we define int‚Å°(s)intùë†\operatorname{int}(s)roman_int ( italic_s ) as the integer interval or the set ùíµùíµ{\cal Z}caligraphic_Z obtained by systematically replacing each function symbol by the application of the int‚Å°(‚ãÖ)int‚ãÖ\operatorname{int}(\cdot)roman_int ( ‚ãÖ ) operation to the corresponding integer set operation. For example, for the extended arithmetic expression s:=(y2‚ãÖz4)/(x2‚ãÖu5)3assignùë†3‚ãÖsuperscriptùë¶2superscriptùëß4‚ãÖsuperscriptùë•2superscriptùë¢5s:=\sqrt[3]{(y^{2}\cdot z^{4})/(x^{2}\cdot u^{5})}italic_s := nth-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG ( italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) / ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG of (2) we have

int‚Å°(s)=int‚Å°(int‚Å°(int‚Å°(Y2)‚ãÖint‚Å°(Z4))/int‚Å°(int‚Å°(X2)‚ãÖint‚Å°(U5))3),intùë†int3int‚ãÖintsuperscriptùëå2intsuperscriptùëç4int‚ãÖintsuperscriptùëã2intsuperscriptùëà5\operatorname{int}(s)=\operatorname{int}(\sqrt[3]{\operatorname{int}(\operatorname{int}(Y^{2})\cdot\operatorname{int}(Z^{4}))/\operatorname{int}(\operatorname{int}(X^{2})\cdot\operatorname{int}(U^{5}))}),roman_int ( italic_s ) = roman_int ( nth-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG roman_int ( roman_int ( italic_Y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚ãÖ roman_int ( italic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) / roman_int ( roman_int ( italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚ãÖ roman_int ( italic_U start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) end_ARG ) ,

where we assume that xùë•xitalic_x ranges over XùëãXitalic_X, etc.

The discussion in the previous subsection shows how to compute int‚Å°(s)intùë†\operatorname{int}(s)roman_int ( italic_s ) given an extended arithmetic expression sùë†sitalic_s and the integer interval domains of its variables.

The following lemma is crucial for our considerations. It is a counterpart of the so-called ‚ÄòFundamental Theorem of Interval Arithmetic‚Äô established in [17]. Because we deal here with the integer domains an additional assumption is needed to establish the desired conclusion.

Lemma 3.2 (Correctness)

Let sùë†sitalic_s be an extended arithmetic expression with the variables x1,‚Ä¶,xnsubscriptùë•1normal-‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëõx_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{n}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Assume that each variable xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of sùë†sitalic_s ranges over an integer interval XisubscriptùëãùëñX_{i}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Choose ai‚ààXisubscriptùëéùëñsubscriptùëãùëña_{i}\in X_{i}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for i‚àà[1..n]i\in[1..n]italic_i ‚àà [ 1 . . italic_n ] and denote by s‚Å¢(a1,‚Ä¶,an)ùë†subscriptùëé1normal-‚Ä¶subscriptùëéùëõs(a_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},a_{n})italic_s ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) the result of replacing in sùë†sitalic_s each occurrence of a variable xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by aisubscriptùëéùëña_{i}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Suppose that each subexpression of s‚Å¢(a1,‚Ä¶,an)ùë†subscriptùëé1normal-‚Ä¶subscriptùëéùëõs(a_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},a_{n})italic_s ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) evaluates to an integer. Then the result of evaluating s‚Å¢(a1,‚Ä¶,an)ùë†subscriptùëé1normal-‚Ä¶subscriptùëéùëõs(a_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},a_{n})italic_s ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is an element of int‚Å°(s)normal-intùë†\operatorname{int}(s)roman_int ( italic_s ).

Proof.¬†The proof follows by a straightforward induction on the structure of sùë†sitalic_s.

‚ñ°‚ñ°\Box‚ñ°

4 An Intermezzo: Constraint Propagation for Linear Constraints

Even though we focus here on arithmetic constraints on integer intervals, it is helpful to realize that the integer interval arithmetic is also useful to define in a succinct way the well-known rules for constraint propagation for linear constraints (studied in detail in [14]). To this end consider first a constraint Œ£i=1n‚Å¢ai‚ãÖxi=b‚ãÖsuperscriptsubscriptŒ£ùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùëéùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñùëè\Sigma_{i=1}^{n}a_{i}\cdot x_{i}=broman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_b, where n‚â•0ùëõ0n\geq 0italic_n ‚â• 0, a1,‚Ä¶,ansubscriptùëé1‚Ä¶subscriptùëéùëõa_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},a_{n}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are non-zero integers, x1,‚Ä¶,xnsubscriptùë•1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëõx_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{n}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are different variables, and bùëèbitalic_b is an integer. We rewrite this constraint nùëõnitalic_n times, each time isolating one variable, to obtain an extended arithmetic expression for each variable xjsubscriptùë•ùëóx_{j}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. To each of these extended arithmetic expressions we apply then the intint\operatorname{int}roman_int operation of Subsection¬†3.3, which yields an update for the domain of the corresponding variable xjsubscriptùë•ùëóx_{j}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. To reason about this procedure we can use the following rule parametrized by j‚àà[1..n]j\in[1..n]italic_j ‚àà [ 1 . . italic_n ]:

LINEAR EQUALITY

‚ü®Œ£i=1n‚Å¢ai‚ãÖxi=b;x1‚ààD1,‚Ä¶,xj‚ààDj,‚Ä¶,xn‚ààDn‚ü©‚ü®Œ£i=1n‚Å¢ai‚ãÖxi=b;x1‚ààD1,‚Ä¶,xj‚ààDj‚Ä≤,‚Ä¶,xn‚ààDn‚ü©delimited-‚ü®‚ü©formulae-sequence‚ãÖsuperscriptsubscriptŒ£ùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùëéùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñùëèformulae-sequencesubscriptùë•1subscriptùê∑1‚Ä¶formulae-sequencesubscriptùë•ùëósubscriptùê∑ùëó‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëõsubscriptùê∑ùëõdelimited-‚ü®‚ü©formulae-sequence‚ãÖsuperscriptsubscriptŒ£ùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùëéùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñùëèformulae-sequencesubscriptùë•1subscriptùê∑1‚Ä¶formulae-sequencesubscriptùë•ùëósubscriptsuperscriptùê∑‚Ä≤ùëó‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëõsubscriptùê∑ùëõ\frac{\langle\Sigma_{i=1}^{n}a_{i}\cdot x_{i}=b\ ;\ x_{1}\in D_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{j}\in D_{j},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{n}\in D_{n}\rangle}{\langle\Sigma_{i=1}^{n}a_{i}\cdot x_{i}=b\ ;\ x_{1}\in D_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{j}\in D^{\prime}_{j},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{n}\in D_{n}\rangle}divide start_ARG ‚ü® roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_b ; italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ü© end_ARG start_ARG ‚ü® roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_b ; italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ü© end_ARG

where Dj‚Ä≤:=Dj‚à©int‚Å°((b‚àíŒ£i‚àà[1..n]‚àí{j}‚Å¢ai‚ãÖxi)/aj)D^{\prime}_{j}:=D_{j}\cap\operatorname{int}\Big{(}(b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..n]-\{j\}}a_{i}\cdot x_{i})/a_{j}\Big{)}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à© roman_int ( ( italic_b - roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà [ 1 . . italic_n ] - { italic_j } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

Note that by virtue of Note 3.1

Dj‚Ä≤=Dj‚à©(b‚àíŒ£i‚àà[1..n]‚àí{j}‚Å¢int‚Å°(ai‚ãÖDi))/aj.D^{\prime}_{j}=D_{j}\cap(b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..n]-\{j\}}\operatorname{int}(a_{i}\cdot D_{i}))/a_{j}.italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à© ( italic_b - roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà [ 1 . . italic_n ] - { italic_j } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_int ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) / italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

To see that this rule preserves equivalence, first note that all our reduction rules compute the domain updates via intersection with the original domain, preventing that domains are extended by their application. Further, suppose that for some d1‚ààD1,‚Ä¶,dn‚ààDnformulae-sequencesubscriptùëë1subscriptùê∑1‚Ä¶subscriptùëëùëõsubscriptùê∑ùëõd_{1}\in D_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},d_{n}\in D_{n}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT we have Œ£i=1n‚Å¢ai‚ãÖdi=b‚ãÖsuperscriptsubscriptŒ£ùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùëéùëñsubscriptùëëùëñùëè\Sigma_{i=1}^{n}a_{i}\cdot d_{i}=broman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_b. Then for j‚àà[1..n]j\in[1..n]italic_j ‚àà [ 1 . . italic_n ] we have

dj=(b‚àíŒ£i‚àà[1..n]‚àí{j}‚Å¢ai‚ãÖdi)/ajd_{j}=(b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..n]-\{j\}}a_{i}\cdot d_{i})/a_{j}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( italic_b - roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà [ 1 . . italic_n ] - { italic_j } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

which by the Correctness Lemma 3.2 implies that

dj‚ààint‚Å°((b‚àíŒ£i‚àà[1..n]‚àí{j}‚Å¢ai‚ãÖxi)/aj),d_{j}\in\operatorname{int}\Big{(}(b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..n]-\{j\}}a_{i}\cdot x_{i})/a_{j}\Big{)},italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà roman_int ( ( italic_b - roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà [ 1 . . italic_n ] - { italic_j } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ,

i.e., dj‚ààDj‚Ä≤subscriptùëëùëósubscriptsuperscriptùê∑‚Ä≤ùëód_{j}\in D^{\prime}_{j}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Next, consider a constraint Œ£i=1n‚Å¢ai‚ãÖxi‚â§b‚ãÖsuperscriptsubscriptŒ£ùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùëéùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñùëè\Sigma_{i=1}^{n}a_{i}\cdot x_{i}\leq broman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ italic_b, where a1,‚Ä¶,an,x1,‚Ä¶,xnsubscriptùëé1‚Ä¶subscriptùëéùëõsubscriptùë•1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëõa_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},a_{n},x_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{n}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and bùëèbitalic_b are as above. To reason about it we can use the following rule parametrized by j‚àà[1..n]j\in[1..n]italic_j ‚àà [ 1 . . italic_n ]:

LINEAR INEQUALITY

‚ü®Œ£i=1n‚Å¢ai‚ãÖxi‚â§b;x1‚ààD1,‚Ä¶,xj‚ààDj,‚Ä¶,xn‚ààDn‚ü©‚ü®Œ£i=1n‚Å¢ai‚ãÖxi‚â§b;x1‚ààD1,‚Ä¶,xj‚ààDj‚Ä≤,‚Ä¶,xn‚ààDn‚ü©delimited-‚ü®‚ü©formulae-sequence‚ãÖsuperscriptsubscriptŒ£ùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùëéùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñùëèformulae-sequencesubscriptùë•1subscriptùê∑1‚Ä¶formulae-sequencesubscriptùë•ùëósubscriptùê∑ùëó‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëõsubscriptùê∑ùëõdelimited-‚ü®‚ü©formulae-sequence‚ãÖsuperscriptsubscriptŒ£ùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùëéùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñùëèformulae-sequencesubscriptùë•1subscriptùê∑1‚Ä¶formulae-sequencesubscriptùë•ùëósubscriptsuperscriptùê∑‚Ä≤ùëó‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëõsubscriptùê∑ùëõ\frac{\langle\Sigma_{i=1}^{n}a_{i}\cdot x_{i}\leq b\ ;\ x_{1}\in D_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{j}\in D_{j},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{n}\in D_{n}\rangle}{\langle\Sigma_{i=1}^{n}a_{i}\cdot x_{i}\leq b\ ;\ x_{1}\in D_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{j}\in D^{\prime}_{j},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{n}\in D_{n}\rangle}divide start_ARG ‚ü® roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ italic_b ; italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ü© end_ARG start_ARG ‚ü® roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ italic_b ; italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ü© end_ARG

where Dj‚Ä≤:=Dj‚à©(‚â§int(b‚àíŒ£i‚àà[1..n]‚àí{j}ai‚ãÖxi)/aj)D^{\prime}_{j}:=D_{j}\cap(^{\leq}\operatorname{int}(b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..n]-\{j\}}a_{i}\cdot x_{i})/a_{j})italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à© ( start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚â§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_int ( italic_b - roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà [ 1 . . italic_n ] - { italic_j } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

To see that this rule preserves equivalence, suppose that for some d1‚ààD1,‚Ä¶,dn‚ààDnformulae-sequencesubscriptùëë1subscriptùê∑1‚Ä¶subscriptùëëùëõsubscriptùê∑ùëõd_{1}\in D_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},d_{n}\in D_{n}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT we have Œ£i=1n‚Å¢ai‚ãÖdi‚â§b‚ãÖsuperscriptsubscriptŒ£ùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùëéùëñsubscriptùëëùëñùëè\Sigma_{i=1}^{n}a_{i}\cdot d_{i}\leq broman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ italic_b. Then aj‚ãÖdj‚â§b‚àíŒ£i‚àà[1..n]‚àí{j}‚Å¢ai‚ãÖdia_{j}\cdot d_{j}\leq b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..n]-\{j\}}a_{i}\cdot d_{i}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ italic_b - roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà [ 1 . . italic_n ] - { italic_j } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. By the Correctness Lemma 3.2

b‚àíŒ£i‚àà[1..n]‚àí{j}‚Å¢ai‚ãÖdi‚ààint‚Å°(b‚àíŒ£i‚àà[1..n]‚àí{j}‚Å¢ai‚ãÖxi),b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..n]-\{j\}}a_{i}\cdot d_{i}\in\operatorname{int}(b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..n]-\{j\}}a_{i}\cdot x_{i}),italic_b - roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà [ 1 . . italic_n ] - { italic_j } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà roman_int ( italic_b - roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà [ 1 . . italic_n ] - { italic_j } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ,

so by definition

aj‚ãÖdj‚àà‚â§int‚Å°(b‚àíŒ£i‚àà[1..n]‚àí{j}‚Å¢ai‚ãÖxi)a_{j}\cdot d_{j}\in^{\leq}\operatorname{int}(b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..n]-\{j\}}a_{i}\cdot x_{i})italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚â§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_int ( italic_b - roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà [ 1 . . italic_n ] - { italic_j } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )

and consequently

dj‚àà‚â§int‚Å°(b‚àíŒ£i‚àà[1..n]‚àí{j}‚Å¢ai‚ãÖxi)/aj.d_{j}\in^{\leq}\operatorname{int}(b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..n]-\{j\}}a_{i}\cdot x_{i})/a_{j}.italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚â§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_int ( italic_b - roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà [ 1 . . italic_n ] - { italic_j } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

This implies that dj‚ààDj‚Ä≤subscriptùëëùëósubscriptsuperscriptùê∑‚Ä≤ùëód_{j}\in D^{\prime}_{j}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

As an alternative to evaluating int‚Å°(Œ£i‚àà[1..n]‚àí{j}‚Å¢ai‚ãÖxi)\operatorname{int}(\Sigma_{i\in[1..n]-\{j\}}a_{i}\cdot x_{i})roman_int ( roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà [ 1 . . italic_n ] - { italic_j } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) on every application of the LINEAR EQUALITY and LINEAR INEQUALITY rules, we could maintain the interval int‚Å°(Œ£1n‚Å¢ai‚ãÖxi)int‚ãÖsuperscriptsubscriptŒ£1ùëõsubscriptùëéùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñ\operatorname{int}(\Sigma_{1}^{n}a_{i}\cdot x_{i})roman_int ( roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) in an auxiliary variable, and subtract int‚Å°(aj‚ãÖxj)int‚ãÖsubscriptùëéùëósubscriptùë•ùëó\operatorname{int}(a_{j}\cdot x_{j})roman_int ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) from it. This corresponds to the two-step propagation described in [14]. If changes to Djsubscriptùê∑ùëóD_{j}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are propagated back to the auxiliary variable, this does not affect the reduction achieved by the subsequent applications of the rules, while the number of interval arithmetic operations involved in the application of a rule becomes constant, instead of linear in the number nùëõnitalic_n of variables.

5 Constraint Propagation: Direct Approach

As a first approach to constraint propagation for arithmetic constraints on integer intervals, we propose to use the constraints directly, in their original form. This is an extension of the approach of Section¬†4 from linear constraints to general arithmetic constraints, and entails that these constraints are rewritten to isolate all occurrences of each variable. The resulting extended arithmetic expressions are then evaluated to obtain updates for the isolated variables.

The following example illustrates this approach. Consider the constraint

x3‚ãÖy‚àíx‚â§40‚ãÖsuperscriptùë•3ùë¶ùë•40x^{3}\cdot y-x\leq 40italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_y - italic_x ‚â§ 40

and the ranges x‚àà[1..100]ùë•delimited-[]1..100x\in[1..100]italic_x ‚àà [ 1..100 ] and y‚àà[1..100]ùë¶delimited-[]1..100y\in[1..100]italic_y ‚àà [ 1..100 ]. We can rewrite it as

x‚â§‚åä(40+x)/y3‚åãùë•340ùë•ùë¶x\leq\left\lfloor\sqrt[3]{(40+x)/y}\right\rflooritalic_x ‚â§ ‚åä nth-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG ( 40 + italic_x ) / italic_y end_ARG ‚åã (3)

since xùë•xitalic_x assumes integer values. The maximum value the expression on the right-hand side can take is ‚åä1403‚åã3140\left\lfloor\sqrt[3]{140}\right\rfloor‚åä nth-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG 140 end_ARG ‚åã, so we conclude x‚â§5ùë•5x\leq 5italic_x ‚â§ 5. By reusing (3), now with the information that x‚àà[1..5]ùë•delimited-[]1..5x\in[1..5]italic_x ‚àà [ 1..5 ], we conclude that the maximum value the expression on the right-hand side of (3) can take is actually ‚åä453‚åã345\left\lfloor\sqrt[3]{45}\right\rfloor‚åä nth-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG 45 end_ARG ‚åã, from which it follows that x‚â§3ùë•3x\leq 3italic_x ‚â§ 3.

In the case of yùë¶yitalic_y we can isolate it by rewriting the original constraint as y‚â§40/x3+1/x2ùë¶40superscriptùë•31superscriptùë•2y\leq 40/x^{3}+1/x^{2}italic_y ‚â§ 40 / italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 1 / italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT from which it follows that y‚â§41ùë¶41y\leq 41italic_y ‚â§ 41, since by assumption x‚â•1ùë•1x\geq 1italic_x ‚â• 1. So we could reduce the domain of xùë•xitalic_x to [1..3]delimited-[]1..3[1..3][ 1..3 ] and the domain of yùë¶yitalic_y to [1..41]delimited-[]1..41[1..41][ 1..41 ]. This interval reduction is optimal, since x=1,y=41formulae-sequenceùë•1ùë¶41x=1,y=41italic_x = 1 , italic_y = 41 and x=3,y=1formulae-sequenceùë•3ùë¶1x=3,y=1italic_x = 3 , italic_y = 1 are both solutions to the original constraint x3‚ãÖy‚àíx‚â§40‚ãÖsuperscriptùë•3ùë¶ùë•40x^{3}\cdot y-x\leq 40italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_y - italic_x ‚â§ 40. So rewriting the constraint as x‚â•x3‚ãÖy‚àí40ùë•‚ãÖsuperscriptùë•3ùë¶40x\geq x^{3}\cdot y-40italic_x ‚â• italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_y - 40 does not yield a new lower bound for xùë•xitalic_x.

More formally, consider a polynomial constraint Œ£i=1m‚Å¢mi=bsubscriptsuperscriptŒ£ùëöùëñ1subscriptùëöùëñùëè\Sigma^{m}_{i=1}m_{i}=broman_Œ£ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_b where m>0ùëö0m>0italic_m > 0, no monomial misubscriptùëöùëñm_{i}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is an integer, the power products of the monomials are pairwise different, and bùëèbitalic_b is an integer. Suppose that x1,‚Ä¶,xnsubscriptùë•1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëõx_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{n}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are its variables ordered w.r.t.¬†‚â∫precedes\prec‚â∫.

Select a non-integer monomial mlsubscriptùëöùëôm_{l}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and assume it is of the form

a‚ãÖy1n1‚ãÖ‚Ä¶‚ãÖyknk,‚ãÖùëésuperscriptsubscriptùë¶1subscriptùëõ1‚Ä¶superscriptsubscriptùë¶ùëòsubscriptùëõùëòa\cdot y_{1}^{n_{1}}\cdot\mbox{$\ldots$}\cdot y_{k}^{n_{k}},italic_a ‚ãÖ italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ ‚Ä¶ ‚ãÖ italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

where k>0ùëò0k>0italic_k > 0, y1,‚Ä¶,yksubscriptùë¶1‚Ä¶subscriptùë¶ùëòy_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},y_{k}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are different variables ordered w.r.t.¬†‚â∫precedes\prec‚â∫, aùëéaitalic_a is a non-zero integer and n1,‚Ä¶,nksubscriptùëõ1‚Ä¶subscriptùëõùëòn_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},n_{k}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are positive integers. So each yisubscriptùë¶ùëñy_{i}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT variable equals to some variable in {x1,‚Ä¶,xn}subscriptùë•1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëõ\{{x_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{n}}\}{ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }. Suppose that ypsubscriptùë¶ùëùy_{p}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT equals to xjsubscriptùë•ùëóx_{j}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We introduce the following proof rule:

POLYNOMIAL EQUALITY

‚ü®Œ£i=1n‚Å¢mi=b;x1‚ààD1,‚Ä¶,xj‚ààDj,‚Ä¶,xn‚ààDn‚ü©‚ü®Œ£i=1n‚Å¢mi=b;x1‚ààD1,‚Ä¶,xj‚ààDj‚Ä≤,‚Ä¶,xn‚ààDn‚ü©delimited-‚ü®‚ü©formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscriptŒ£ùëõùëñ1subscriptùëöùëñùëèformulae-sequencesubscriptùë•1subscriptùê∑1‚Ä¶formulae-sequencesubscriptùë•ùëósubscriptùê∑ùëó‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëõsubscriptùê∑ùëõdelimited-‚ü®‚ü©formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscriptŒ£ùëõùëñ1subscriptùëöùëñùëèformulae-sequencesubscriptùë•1subscriptùê∑1‚Ä¶formulae-sequencesubscriptùë•ùëósubscriptsuperscriptùê∑‚Ä≤ùëó‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëõsubscriptùê∑ùëõ\frac{\langle\Sigma^{n}_{i=1}m_{i}=b\ ;\ x_{1}\in D_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{j}\in D_{j},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{n}\in D_{n}\rangle}{\langle\Sigma^{n}_{i=1}m_{i}=b\ ;\ x_{1}\in D_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{j}\in D^{\prime}_{j},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{n}\in D_{n}\rangle}divide start_ARG ‚ü® roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_b ; italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ü© end_ARG start_ARG ‚ü® roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_b ; italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ü© end_ARG

where Dj‚Ä≤:=int‚Å°(Dj‚à©int‚Å°((b‚àíŒ£i‚àà[1..m]‚àí{l}‚Å¢mi)/s)np)D^{\prime}_{j}:=\operatorname{int}\left(D_{j}\cap\sqrt[n_{p}]{\operatorname{int}\left(({b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..m]-\{{l}\}}m_{i}})/s\right)}\ \right)italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à© nth-root start_ARG italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG roman_int ( ( italic_b - roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà [ 1 . . italic_m ] - { italic_l } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_s ) end_ARG ), with s:=a‚ãÖy1n1‚ãÖ‚Ä¶‚ãÖyp‚àí1np‚àí1‚ãÖyp+1np+1‚Å¢‚Ä¶‚ãÖyknkassignùë†‚ãÖ‚ãÖùëésuperscriptsubscriptùë¶1subscriptùëõ1‚Ä¶superscriptsubscriptùë¶ùëù1subscriptùëõùëù1superscriptsubscriptùë¶ùëù1subscriptùëõùëù1‚Ä¶superscriptsubscriptùë¶ùëòsubscriptùëõùëòs:=a\cdot y_{1}^{n_{1}}\cdot\mbox{$\ldots$}\cdot y_{p-1}^{n_{p-1}}\cdot y_{p+1}^{n_{p+1}}\mbox{$\ldots$}\cdot y_{k}^{n_{k}}italic_s := italic_a ‚ãÖ italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ ‚Ä¶ ‚ãÖ italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä¶ ‚ãÖ italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

To see that this rule preserves equivalence, choose some d1‚ààD1,‚Ä¶,dn‚ààDnformulae-sequencesubscriptùëë1subscriptùê∑1‚Ä¶subscriptùëëùëõsubscriptùê∑ùëõd_{1}\in D_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},d_{n}\in D_{n}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. To simplify the notation, given an extended arithmetic expression tùë°titalic_t denote by t‚Ä≤superscriptùë°‚Ä≤t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT the result of evaluating tùë°titalic_t after each occurrence of a variable xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is replaced by disubscriptùëëùëñd_{i}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Suppose that Œ£i=1m‚Å¢mi‚Ä≤=bsuperscriptsubscriptŒ£ùëñ1ùëösubscriptsuperscriptùëö‚Ä≤ùëñùëè\Sigma_{i=1}^{m}m^{\prime}_{i}=broman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_b. Then
