djnp‚ãÖs‚Ä≤=b‚àíŒ£i‚àà[1..m]‚àí{l}‚Å¢mi‚Ä≤,d_{j}^{n_{p}}\cdot s^{\prime}=b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..m]-\{{l}\}}m^{\prime}_{i},italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_b - roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà [ 1 . . italic_m ] - { italic_l } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

so by the Correctness Lemma 3.2 applied to b‚àíŒ£i‚àà[1..m]‚àí{l}‚Å¢mi‚Ä≤b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..m]-\{{l}\}}m^{\prime}_{i}italic_b - roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà [ 1 . . italic_m ] - { italic_l } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and to sùë†sitalic_s

djnp‚ààint‚Å°(b‚àíŒ£i‚àà[1..m]‚àí{l}‚Å¢mi)/int‚Å°(s).d_{j}^{n_{p}}\in\operatorname{int}(b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..m]-\{{l}\}}m_{i})/\operatorname{int}(s).italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àà roman_int ( italic_b - roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà [ 1 . . italic_m ] - { italic_l } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / roman_int ( italic_s ) .

Hence

dj‚ààint‚Å°(b‚àíŒ£i‚àà[1..m]‚àí{l}‚Å¢mi)/int‚Å°(s)npd_{j}\in\sqrt[n_{p}]{\operatorname{int}(b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..m]-\{{l}\}}m_{i})/\operatorname{int}(s)}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà nth-root start_ARG italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG roman_int ( italic_b - roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà [ 1 . . italic_m ] - { italic_l } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / roman_int ( italic_s ) end_ARG

and consequently

dj‚ààint‚Å°(Dj‚à©int‚Å°((b‚àíŒ£i‚àà[1..m]‚àí{l}‚Å¢mi)/s)np)d_{j}\in\operatorname{int}\left(D_{j}\cap\sqrt[n_{p}]{\operatorname{int}\left(({b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..m]-\{{l}\}}m_{i}})/s\right)}\ \right)italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à© nth-root start_ARG italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG roman_int ( ( italic_b - roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà [ 1 . . italic_m ] - { italic_l } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_s ) end_ARG )

i.e., dj‚ààDj‚Ä≤subscriptùëëùëósubscriptsuperscriptùê∑‚Ä≤ùëód_{j}\in D^{\prime}_{j}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Note that we do not apply int‚Å°(‚ãÖ)int‚ãÖ\operatorname{int}(\cdot)roman_int ( ‚ãÖ ) to the outcome of the root extraction operation. For even npsubscriptùëõùëùn_{p}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT this means that the second operand of the intersection can be a union of two intervals, instead of a single interval. To see why this is desirable, consider the constraint x2‚àíy=0superscriptùë•2ùë¶0x^{2}-y=0italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_y = 0 in the presence of ranges x‚àà[0..10]ùë•delimited-[]0..10x\in[0..10]italic_x ‚àà [ 0..10 ], y‚àà[25..100]ùë¶delimited-[]25..100y\in[25..100]italic_y ‚àà [ 25..100 ]. Using the int‚Å°(‚ãÖ)int‚ãÖ\operatorname{int}(\cdot)roman_int ( ‚ãÖ ) closure of the root extraction we would not be able to update the lower bound of xùë•xitalic_x to 5.

Next, consider a polynomial constraint Œ£i=1m‚Å¢mi‚â§b.subscriptsuperscriptŒ£ùëöùëñ1subscriptùëöùëñùëè\Sigma^{m}_{i=1}m_{i}\leq b.roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ italic_b . Below we adopt the assumptions and notation used when defining the POLYNOMIAL EQUALITY rule. To formulate the appropriate rule we stipulate that for the extended arithmetic expressions sùë†sitalic_s and tùë°titalic_t

int((‚â§s)/t):=‚â•Q‚à©‚â§Q,\operatorname{int}((^{\leq}s)/t)\ :=\ ^{\geq}Q\cap\ ^{\leq}Q,roman_int ( ( start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚â§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s ) / italic_t ) := start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚â• end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Q ‚à© start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚â§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Q ,

with Q=(‚â§int(s))/int(t)Q=(^{\leq}\operatorname{int}(s))/\operatorname{int}(t)italic_Q = ( start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚â§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_int ( italic_s ) ) / roman_int ( italic_t ).

To reason about this constraint we use the following rule:

POLYNOMIAL INEQUALITY

‚ü®Œ£i=1n‚Å¢mi‚â§b;x1‚ààD1,‚Ä¶,xj‚ààDj,‚Ä¶,xn‚ààDn‚ü©‚ü®Œ£i=1n‚Å¢mi‚â§b;x1‚ààD1,‚Ä¶,xj‚ààDj‚Ä≤,‚Ä¶,xn‚ààDn‚ü©delimited-‚ü®‚ü©formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscriptŒ£ùëõùëñ1subscriptùëöùëñùëèformulae-sequencesubscriptùë•1subscriptùê∑1‚Ä¶formulae-sequencesubscriptùë•ùëósubscriptùê∑ùëó‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëõsubscriptùê∑ùëõdelimited-‚ü®‚ü©formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscriptŒ£ùëõùëñ1subscriptùëöùëñùëèformulae-sequencesubscriptùë•1subscriptùê∑1‚Ä¶formulae-sequencesubscriptùë•ùëósubscriptsuperscriptùê∑‚Ä≤ùëó‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëõsubscriptùê∑ùëõ\frac{\langle\Sigma^{n}_{i=1}m_{i}\leq b\ ;\ x_{1}\in D_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{j}\in D_{j},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{n}\in D_{n}\rangle}{\langle\Sigma^{n}_{i=1}m_{i}\leq b\ ;\ x_{1}\in D_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{j}\in D^{\prime}_{j},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{n}\in D_{n}\rangle}divide start_ARG ‚ü® roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ italic_b ; italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ü© end_ARG start_ARG ‚ü® roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ italic_b ; italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ü© end_ARG

where Dj‚Ä≤:=int‚Å°(Dj‚à©int((b‚àíŒ£i‚àà[1..m]‚àí{l}mi)‚â§/s)np)D^{\prime}_{j}:=\operatorname{int}\left(D_{j}\cap\sqrt[n_{p}]{\operatorname{int}\left({}^{\leq}(b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..m]-\{{l}\}}m_{i})/s\right)}\ \right)italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à© nth-root start_ARG italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG roman_int ( start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT ‚â§ end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_b - roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà [ 1 . . italic_m ] - { italic_l } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_s ) end_ARG ), with s:=a‚ãÖy1n1‚ãÖ‚Ä¶‚ãÖyp‚àí1np‚àí1‚ãÖyp+1np+1‚Å¢‚Ä¶‚ãÖyknkassignùë†‚ãÖ‚ãÖùëésuperscriptsubscriptùë¶1subscriptùëõ1‚Ä¶superscriptsubscriptùë¶ùëù1subscriptùëõùëù1superscriptsubscriptùë¶ùëù1subscriptùëõùëù1‚Ä¶superscriptsubscriptùë¶ùëòsubscriptùëõùëòs:=a\cdot y_{1}^{n_{1}}\cdot\mbox{$\ldots$}\cdot y_{p-1}^{n_{p-1}}\cdot y_{p+1}^{n_{p+1}}\mbox{$\ldots$}\cdot y_{k}^{n_{k}}italic_s := italic_a ‚ãÖ italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ ‚Ä¶ ‚ãÖ italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä¶ ‚ãÖ italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

To prove that this rule preserves equivalence, choose some d1‚ààD1,‚Ä¶,dn‚ààDnformulae-sequencesubscriptùëë1subscriptùê∑1‚Ä¶subscriptùëëùëõsubscriptùê∑ùëõd_{1}\in D_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},d_{n}\in D_{n}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. As above given an extended arithmetic expression tùë°titalic_t we denote by t‚Ä≤superscriptùë°‚Ä≤t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT the result of evaluating tùë°titalic_t when each occurrence of a variable xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in tùë°titalic_t is replaced by disubscriptùëëùëñd_{i}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Suppose that Œ£i=1m‚Å¢mi‚Ä≤‚â§bsuperscriptsubscriptŒ£ùëñ1ùëösubscriptsuperscriptùëö‚Ä≤ùëñùëè\Sigma_{i=1}^{m}m^{\prime}_{i}\leq broman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ italic_b. Then

djnp‚ãÖs‚Ä≤‚â§b‚àíŒ£i‚àà[1..m]‚àí{l}‚Å¢mi‚Ä≤.d_{j}^{n_{p}}\cdot s^{\prime}\leq b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..m]-\{{l}\}}m^{\prime}_{i}.italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚â§ italic_b - roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà [ 1 . . italic_m ] - { italic_l } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

By the Correctness Lemma 3.2

b‚àíŒ£i‚àà[1..m]‚àí{l}‚Å¢mi‚Ä≤‚ààint‚Å°(b‚àíŒ£i‚àà[1..m]‚àí{l}‚Å¢mi),b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..m]-\{{l}\}}m^{\prime}_{i}\in\operatorname{int}(b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..m]-\{{l}\}}m_{i}),italic_b - roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà [ 1 . . italic_m ] - { italic_l } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà roman_int ( italic_b - roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà [ 1 . . italic_m ] - { italic_l } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ,

so by definition

djnp‚ãÖs‚Ä≤‚àà‚â§int‚Å°(b‚àíŒ£i‚àà[1..m]‚àí{l}‚Å¢mi).d_{j}^{n_{p}}\cdot s^{\prime}\in^{\leq}\operatorname{int}(b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..m]-\{{l}\}}m_{i}).italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àà start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚â§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_int ( italic_b - roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà [ 1 . . italic_m ] - { italic_l } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) .

Hence by the definition of the division operation on the sets of integers

djnp‚àà‚â§int‚Å°(b‚àíŒ£i‚àà[1..m]‚àí{l}‚Å¢mi)/int‚Å°(s)d_{j}^{n_{p}}\in^{\leq}\operatorname{int}(b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..m]-\{{l}\}}m_{i})/\operatorname{int}(s)italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àà start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚â§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_int ( italic_b - roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà [ 1 . . italic_m ] - { italic_l } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / roman_int ( italic_s )

Consequently

dj‚ààint‚â§‚Å°(b‚àíŒ£i‚àà[1..m]‚àí{l}‚Å¢mi)/int‚Å°(s)np.d_{j}\in\sqrt[n_{p}]{{}^{\leq}\operatorname{int}(b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..m]-\{{l}\}}m_{i})/\operatorname{int}(s)}.italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà nth-root start_ARG italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT ‚â§ end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT roman_int ( italic_b - roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà [ 1 . . italic_m ] - { italic_l } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / roman_int ( italic_s ) end_ARG .

This implies that dj‚ààDj‚Ä≤subscriptùëëùëósubscriptsuperscriptùê∑‚Ä≤ùëód_{j}\in D^{\prime}_{j}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Note that the set int‚â§‚Å°(b‚àíŒ£i‚àà[1..m]‚àí{l}‚Å¢mi){}^{\leq}\operatorname{int}(b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..m]-\{{l}\}}m_{i})start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT ‚â§ end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT roman_int ( italic_b - roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà [ 1 . . italic_m ] - { italic_l } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), which occurs when the expression for Dj‚Ä≤subscriptsuperscriptùê∑‚Ä≤ùëóD^{\prime}_{j}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is expanded according to the above definition of int((‚â§s)/t)\operatorname{int}((^{\leq}s)/t)roman_int ( ( start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚â§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s ) / italic_t ), is not an interval. So to properly implement this rule we need to extend the implementation of the division operation discussed in Subsection 3.2 to the case when the numerator is an extended interval.

If the sum of the intervals associated with each of the monomials in a polynomial constraint is maintained in an auxiliary variable, as we discussed at the end of Section¬†4 for linear constraints,¬†then the rules can be applied using a constant number of interval additions. However, interval division is not the inverse operation of interval multiplication, so the same technique cannot be applied to monomials, and the number of multiplications and exponentiations will be linear in the size of the monomial sùë†sitalic_s.

In an optimized version of the direct approach we simplify the fractions of two polynomials by splitting the division over addition and subtraction and by dividing out common powers of variables and greatest common divisors of the constant factors. Subsequently, fractions whose denominators have identical power products are added. We used this optimization in the initial example by simplifying (40+x)/x340ùë•superscriptùë•3(40+x)/x^{3}( 40 + italic_x ) / italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to 40/x3+1/x240superscriptùë•31superscriptùë•240/x^{3}+1/x^{2}40 / italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 1 / italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The reader may check that without this simplification step we can only deduce that y‚â§43ùë¶43y\leq 43italic_y ‚â§ 43.

To provide details of this optimization, given two monomials sùë†sitalic_s and tùë°titalic_t, we denote by

[s/t]delimited-[]ùë†ùë°[s/t][ italic_s / italic_t ]

the result of performing this simplification operation on sùë†sitalic_s and tùë°titalic_t. For example, [(2‚ãÖx3‚ãÖy)/(4‚ãÖx2)]delimited-[]‚ãÖ2superscriptùë•3ùë¶‚ãÖ4superscriptùë•2[(2\cdot x^{3}\cdot y)/(4\cdot x^{2})][ ( 2 ‚ãÖ italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_y ) / ( 4 ‚ãÖ italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] equals (x‚ãÖy)/2‚ãÖùë•ùë¶2(x\cdot y)/2( italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y ) / 2, whereas [(4‚ãÖx3‚ãÖy)/(2‚ãÖy2)]delimited-[]‚ãÖ4superscriptùë•3ùë¶‚ãÖ2superscriptùë¶2[(4\cdot x^{3}\cdot y)/(2\cdot y^{2})][ ( 4 ‚ãÖ italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_y ) / ( 2 ‚ãÖ italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] equals (2‚ãÖx3)/y‚ãÖ2superscriptùë•3ùë¶(2\cdot x^{3})/y( 2 ‚ãÖ italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) / italic_y.

Because the validity of the simplification depends on the sign of the denominator, we assume that the domains of the variables y1,‚Ä¶,yp‚àí1subscriptùë¶1‚Ä¶subscriptùë¶ùëù1y_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},y_{p-1}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, yp+1,‚Ä¶,ynsubscriptùë¶ùëù1‚Ä¶subscriptùë¶ùëõy_{p+1},\mbox{$\ldots$},y_{n}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of mlsubscriptùëöùëôm_{l}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT do not contain 0. For a monomial sùë†sitalic_s involving variables ranging over the integer intervals that do not contain 0, the set int‚Å°(s)intùë†\operatorname{int}(s)roman_int ( italic_s ) either contains only positive numbers or only negative numbers. In the first case we write sign‚Å°(s)=+signùë†\operatorname{sign}(s)=+roman_sign ( italic_s ) = + and in the second case we write sign‚Å°(s)=‚àísignùë†\operatorname{sign}(s)=-roman_sign ( italic_s ) = -.

The new domain of the variable xjsubscriptùë•ùëóx_{j}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in the POLYNOMIAL INEQUALITY rule is defined using two sequences m0‚Ä≤‚Å¢‚Ä¶‚Å¢mn‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùëö0‚Ä≤‚Ä¶superscriptsubscriptùëöùëõ‚Ä≤m_{0}^{\prime}...m_{n}^{\prime}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä¶ italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and s0‚Ä≤‚Å¢‚Ä¶‚Å¢sn‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùë†0‚Ä≤‚Ä¶superscriptsubscriptùë†ùëõ‚Ä≤s_{0}^{\prime}...s_{n}^{\prime}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä¶ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of extended arithmetic expressions such that

m0‚Ä≤/s0‚Ä≤=[b/s]‚Å¢and‚Å¢mi‚Ä≤/si‚Ä≤=‚àí[mi/s]‚Å¢for¬†i‚àà[1..m].superscriptsubscriptùëö0‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùë†0‚Ä≤delimited-[]ùëèùë†andsuperscriptsubscriptùëöùëñ‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùë†ùëñ‚Ä≤delimited-[]subscriptùëöùëñùë†for¬†i‚àà[1..m].m_{0}^{\prime}/s_{0}^{\prime}=[b/s]\ \textrm{and}\ m_{i}^{\prime}/s_{i}^{\prime}=-[m_{i}/s]\ \textrm{for $i\in[1..m]$.}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ italic_b / italic_s ] and italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = - [ italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_s ] for italic_i ‚àà [ 1 . . italic_m ] .

Let S:={si‚Ä≤‚à£i‚àà[0..m]‚àí{l}}S:=\{s_{i}^{\prime}\mid i\in[0..m]-\{{l}\}\}italic_S := { italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à£ italic_i ‚àà [ 0 . . italic_m ] - { italic_l } } and for an extended arithmetic expression t‚ààSùë°ùëÜt\in Sitalic_t ‚àà italic_S let It:={i‚àà[0..m]‚àí{l}‚à£si‚Ä≤=t}I_{t}:=\{i\in[0..m]-\{{l}\}\mid s_{i}^{\prime}=t\}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := { italic_i ‚àà [ 0 . . italic_m ] - { italic_l } ‚à£ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_t }. We denote then by ptsubscriptùëùùë°p_{t}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT the polynomial ‚àëi‚ààItmi‚Ä≤subscriptùëñsubscriptùêºùë°superscriptsubscriptùëöùëñ‚Ä≤\sum_{i\in I_{t}}{m_{i}^{\prime}}‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The new domains are then defined by

Dj‚Ä≤:=int‚Å°(Dj‚à©int‚â§‚Å°(Œ£t‚ààS‚Å¢pt‚äòt)np)assignsubscriptsuperscriptùê∑‚Ä≤ùëóintsubscriptùê∑ùëósubscriptùëõùëùsuperscriptint‚äòsubscriptŒ£ùë°ùëÜsubscriptùëùùë°ùë°D^{\prime}_{j}:=\operatorname{int}\left(D_{j}\cap\sqrt[n_{p}]{{}^{\leq}\operatorname{int}\left(\Sigma_{t\in S}\ p_{t}\oslash t\right)}\ \right)italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à© nth-root start_ARG italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT ‚â§ end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT roman_int ( roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t ‚àà italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚äò italic_t ) end_ARG )

if sign‚Å°(s)=+signùë†\operatorname{sign}(s)=+roman_sign ( italic_s ) = +, and by

Dj‚Ä≤:=int‚Å°(Dj‚à©int‚â•‚Å°(Œ£t‚ààS‚Å¢pt‚äòt)np)assignsubscriptsuperscriptùê∑‚Ä≤ùëóintsubscriptùê∑ùëósubscriptùëõùëùsuperscriptint‚äòsubscriptŒ£ùë°ùëÜsubscriptùëùùë°ùë°D^{\prime}_{j}:=\operatorname{int}\left(D_{j}\cap\sqrt[n_{p}]{{}^{\geq}\operatorname{int}\left(\Sigma_{t\in S}\ p_{t}\oslash t\right)}\ \right)italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à© nth-root start_ARG italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT ‚â• end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT roman_int ( roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t ‚àà italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚äò italic_t ) end_ARG )

if sign‚Å°(s)=‚àísignùë†\operatorname{sign}(s)=-roman_sign ( italic_s ) = -. Here the int‚Å°(s)intùë†\operatorname{int}(s)roman_int ( italic_s ) notation used in the Correctness Lemma 3.2 is extended to expressions involving the division operator ‚äò‚äò\oslash‚äò on real intervals in the obvious way. We define the int‚Å°(‚ãÖ)int‚ãÖ\operatorname{int}(\cdot)roman_int ( ‚ãÖ ) operator applied to a bounded set of reals, as produced by the division and addition operators in the above two expressions for Dj‚Ä≤subscriptsuperscriptùê∑‚Ä≤ùëóD^{\prime}_{j}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, to denote the smallest interval of reals containing that set.

Returning again to the discussion of the two-step propagation technique of [14], which we started at the end of Section¬†4, note that in this case, the int‚Å°(‚ãÖ)int‚ãÖ\operatorname{int}(\cdot)roman_int ( ‚ãÖ ) operation is applied after removing the common power products. For this reason, there is no straightforward way to calculate int‚Å°(Œ£t‚ààS‚Å¢pt‚äòt)int‚äòsubscriptŒ£ùë°ùëÜsubscriptùëùùë°ùë°\operatorname{int}(\Sigma_{t\in S}\ p_{t}\oslash t)roman_int ( roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t ‚àà italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚äò italic_t ) from the sum of all intervals associated with the monomials of a polynomial constraint.

6 Constraint Propagation: Partial Decomposition

As a second approach to constraint propagation for arithmetic constraints on integer intervals, we limit our attention to a special type of polynomial constraints, namely the ones of the form s‚Å¢o‚Å¢p‚Å¢bùë†ùëúùëùùëès\ op\ bitalic_s italic_o italic_p italic_b, where sùë†sitalic_s is a polynomial in which each variable occurs at most once and where bùëèbitalic_b is an integer. We call such a constraint a simple polynomial constraint. By introducing auxiliary variables that are equated with appropriate monomials we can decompose any polynomial constraint into a sequence of simple polynomial constraints. This allows us also to compute the integer interval domains of the auxiliary variable from the integer interval domains of the original variables. We apply then to the simple polynomial constraints the rules introduced in the previous section.

To see that the restriction to simple polynomial constraints can make a difference consider the constraint

100‚Å¢x‚ãÖy‚àí10‚Å¢y‚ãÖz=212,‚ãÖ100ùë•ùë¶‚ãÖ10ùë¶ùëß212100x\cdot y-10y\cdot z=212,100 italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y - 10 italic_y ‚ãÖ italic_z = 212 ,

and ranges x,y,z‚àà[1..9]ùë•ùë¶ùëßdelimited-[]1..9x,y,z\in[1..9]italic_x , italic_y , italic_z ‚àà [ 1..9 ]. We rewrite it into the sequence

u=x‚ãÖy,v=y‚ãÖz, 100‚Å¢u‚àí10‚Å¢v=212,formulae-sequenceùë¢‚ãÖùë•ùë¶formulae-sequenceùë£‚ãÖùë¶ùëß100ùë¢10ùë£212u=x\cdot y,\ v=y\cdot z,\ 100u-10v=212,italic_u = italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y , italic_v = italic_y ‚ãÖ italic_z , 100 italic_u - 10 italic_v = 212 ,

where u,vùë¢ùë£u,vitalic_u , italic_v are auxiliary variables, each with the domain [1..81]delimited-[]1..81[1..81][ 1..81 ].

It is easy to check that the POLYNOMIAL EQUALITY rule introduced in the previous section does not yield any domain reduction when applied to the original constraint 100‚Å¢x‚ãÖy‚àí10‚Å¢y‚ãÖz=212‚ãÖ100ùë•ùë¶‚ãÖ10ùë¶ùëß212100x\cdot y-10y\cdot z=212100 italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y - 10 italic_y ‚ãÖ italic_z = 212. In the presence of the discussed optimization the domain of xùë•xitalic_x gets reduced to [1..3]delimited-[]1..3[1..3][ 1..3 ].

However, if we repeatedly apply the POLYNOMIAL EQUALITY rule to the simple polynomial constraint 100‚Å¢u‚àí10‚Å¢v=212100ùë¢10ùë£212100u-10v=212100 italic_u - 10 italic_v = 212, we eventually reduce the domain of uùë¢uitalic_u to the empty set (since this constraint has no integer solution in the ranges u,v‚àà[1..81]ùë¢ùë£delimited-[]1..81u,v\in[1..81]italic_u , italic_v ‚àà [ 1..81 ]) and consequently can conclude that the original constraint 100‚Å¢x‚ãÖy‚àí10‚Å¢y‚ãÖz=212‚ãÖ100ùë•ùë¶‚ãÖ10ùë¶ùëß212100x\cdot y-10y\cdot z=212100 italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y - 10 italic_y ‚ãÖ italic_z = 212 has no solution in the ranges x,y,z‚àà[1..9]ùë•ùë¶ùëßdelimited-[]1..9x,y,z\in[1..9]italic_x , italic_y , italic_z ‚àà [ 1..9 ], without performing any search. Note that this effect still occurs if we replace one occurrence of yùë¶yitalic_y by a fresh variable with the same domain.

As noted in [8], decomposing constraints also prevents the evaluation of subexpressions whose domains did not change, which may reduce the number of interval arithmetic operations performed during constraint propagation. In our case duplicate occurrences of variables are removed, so the reduction rules additionally become idempotent. However, this can be seen as a side-effect: rules still update variables that they depend on, only now this update is indirect, through other variables.

Consider for example the constraint x3‚ãÖy‚àíx‚â§40‚ãÖsuperscriptùë•3ùë¶ùë•40x^{3}\cdot y-x\leq 40italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_y - italic_x ‚â§ 40 of Section¬†5. If we rewrite this constraint as u‚àíx‚â§40ùë¢ùë•40u-x\leq 40italic_u - italic_x ‚â§ 40, with u=x3‚ãÖyùë¢‚ãÖsuperscriptùë•3ùë¶u=x^{3}\cdot yitalic_u = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_y and x,y‚àà[1..100]ùë•ùë¶delimited-[]1..100x,y\in[1..100]italic_x , italic_y ‚àà [ 1..100 ], then via u‚â§x+40ùë¢ùë•40u\leq x+40italic_u ‚â§ italic_x + 40 we can set the upper bound for uùë¢uitalic_u to 140. Via x=u/y3ùë•3ùë¢ùë¶x=\sqrt[3]{u/y}italic_x = nth-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG italic_u / italic_y end_ARG we can then set the upper for xùë•xitalic_x to 5. This allows us to set the upper bound for uùë¢uitalic_u to 45 via u‚â§x+40ùë¢ùë•40u\leq x+40italic_u ‚â§ italic_x + 40, etc. From this point of view the auxiliary variables, and the idempotence that they entail, can be seen as an optimization that prevents the evaluation of expressions that will not lead to further domain updates.

7 Constraint Propagation: Full Decomposition

In this third approach we focus on a small set of ‚Äòatomic‚Äô arithmetic constraints. We call an arithmetic constraint atomic if it is in one of the following two forms:

  • ‚Ä¢

    a linear constraint,

  • ‚Ä¢

    x‚ãÖy=z‚ãÖùë•ùë¶ùëßx\cdot y=zitalic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y = italic_z.

Using appropriate transformation rules involving auxiliary variables we can decompose any arithmetic constraint to a sequence of atomic arithmetic constraints, similar to the decomposition of linear constraints into constraints on groups of three variables in clp(FD) [8]. In this transformation, as with partial decomposition, the auxiliary variables are equated with monomials, so we can easily compute their domains.

We explained already in Section 4 how to reason about linear constraints. For a treatment of disequalities see, e.g., [14, 20]. Next, we focus on the reasoning for the multiplication constraint x‚ãÖy=z‚ãÖùë•ùë¶ùëßx\cdot y=zitalic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y = italic_z in the presence of the non-empty ranges x‚ààDxùë•subscriptùê∑ùë•x\in D_{x}italic_x ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, y‚ààDyùë¶subscriptùê∑ùë¶y\in D_{y}italic_y ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and z‚ààDzùëßsubscriptùê∑ùëßz\in D_{z}italic_z ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. To this end we introduce the following three domain reduction rules:

MULTIPLICATION 1

‚ü®x‚ãÖy=z;x‚ààDx,y‚ààDy,z‚ààDz‚ü©‚ü®x‚ãÖy=z;x‚ààDx,y‚ààDy,z‚ààDz‚Ä≤‚ü©delimited-‚ü®‚ü©formulae-sequence‚ãÖùë•ùë¶ùëßformulae-sequenceùë•subscriptùê∑ùë•formulae-sequenceùë¶subscriptùê∑ùë¶ùëßsubscriptùê∑ùëßdelimited-‚ü®‚ü©formulae-sequence‚ãÖùë•ùë¶ùëßformulae-sequenceùë•subscriptùê∑ùë•formulae-sequenceùë¶subscriptùê∑ùë¶ùëßsuperscriptsubscriptùê∑ùëß‚Ä≤\frac{\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in D_{x},y\in D_{y},z\in D_{z}\rangle}{\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in D_{x},y\in D_{y},z\in D_{z}^{\prime}\rangle}divide start_ARG ‚ü® italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ü© end_ARG start_ARG ‚ü® italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ü© end_ARG

MULTIPLICATION 2

‚ü®x‚ãÖy=z;x‚ààDx,y‚ààDy,z‚ààDz‚ü©‚ü®x‚ãÖy=z;x‚ààDx‚Ä≤,y‚ààDy,z‚ààDz‚ü©delimited-‚ü®‚ü©formulae-sequence‚ãÖùë•ùë¶ùëßformulae-sequenceùë•subscriptùê∑ùë•formulae-sequenceùë¶subscriptùê∑ùë¶ùëßsubscriptùê∑ùëßdelimited-‚ü®‚ü©formulae-sequence‚ãÖùë•ùë¶ùëßformulae-sequenceùë•superscriptsubscriptùê∑ùë•‚Ä≤formulae-sequenceùë¶subscriptùê∑ùë¶ùëßsubscriptùê∑ùëß\frac{\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in D_{x},y\in D_{y},z\in D_{z}\rangle}{\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in D_{x}^{\prime},y\in D_{y},z\in D_{z}\rangle}divide start_ARG ‚ü® italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ü© end_ARG start_ARG ‚ü® italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_y ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ü© end_ARG

MULTIPLICATION 3

‚ü®x‚ãÖy=z;x‚ààDx,y‚ààDy,z‚ààDz‚ü©‚ü®x‚ãÖy=z;x‚ààDx,y‚ààDy‚Ä≤,z‚ààDz‚ü©delimited-‚ü®‚ü©formulae-sequence‚ãÖùë•ùë¶ùëßformulae-sequenceùë•subscriptùê∑ùë•formulae-sequenceùë¶subscriptùê∑ùë¶ùëßsubscriptùê∑ùëßdelimited-‚ü®‚ü©formulae-sequence‚ãÖùë•ùë¶ùëßformulae-sequenceùë•subscriptùê∑ùë•formulae-sequenceùë¶superscriptsubscriptùê∑ùë¶‚Ä≤ùëßsubscriptùê∑ùëß\frac{\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in D_{x},y\in D_{y},z\in D_{z}\rangle}{\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in D_{x},y\in D_{y}^{\prime},z\in D_{z}\rangle}divide start_ARG ‚ü® italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ü© end_ARG start_ARG ‚ü® italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_z ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ü© end_ARG

where Dz‚Ä≤:=Dz‚à©int‚Å°(Dx‚ãÖDy)assignsuperscriptsubscriptùê∑ùëß‚Ä≤subscriptùê∑ùëßint‚ãÖsubscriptùê∑ùë•subscriptùê∑ùë¶D_{z}^{\prime}:=D_{z}\cap\operatorname{int}(D_{x}\cdot D_{y})italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à© roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ãÖ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), Dx‚Ä≤:=Dx‚à©int‚Å°(Dz/Dy)assignsuperscriptsubscriptùê∑ùë•‚Ä≤subscriptùê∑ùë•intsubscriptùê∑ùëßsubscriptùê∑ùë¶D_{x}^{\prime}:=D_{x}\cap\operatorname{int}(D_{z}/D_{y})italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à© roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), and Dy‚Ä≤:=Dy‚à©int‚Å°(Dz/Dx)assignsuperscriptsubscriptùê∑ùë¶‚Ä≤subscriptùê∑ùë¶intsubscriptùê∑ùëßsubscriptùê∑ùë•D_{y}^{\prime}:=D_{y}\cap\operatorname{int}(D_{z}/D_{x})italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à© roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

The way we defined the multiplication and the division of the integer intervals ensures that the MULTIPLICATION rules 1,2, and 3 are equivalence preserving. Consider for example the MULTIPLICATION 2 rule. Take some a‚ààDx,b‚ààDyformulae-sequenceùëésubscriptùê∑ùë•ùëèsubscriptùê∑ùë¶a\in D_{x},b\in D_{y}italic_a ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_b ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and c‚ààDzùëêsubscriptùê∑ùëßc\in D_{z}italic_c ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that a‚ãÖb=c‚ãÖùëéùëèùëêa\cdot b=citalic_a ‚ãÖ italic_b = italic_c. Then a‚àà{x‚ààùíµ‚à£‚àÉz‚ààDz‚Å¢‚àÉy‚ààDy‚Å¢x‚ãÖy=z}ùëéconditional-setùë•ùíµùëßsubscriptùê∑ùëßùë¶‚ãÖsubscriptùê∑ùë¶ùë•ùë¶ùëßa\in\mbox{$\{{x\in{\cal Z}\mid\mbox{$\exists$}z\in D_{z}\mbox{$\exists$}y\in D_{y}\>x\cdot y=z}\}$}italic_a ‚àà { italic_x ‚àà caligraphic_Z ‚à£ ‚àÉ italic_z ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àÉ italic_y ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y = italic_z }, so a‚ààDz/Dyùëésubscriptùê∑ùëßsubscriptùê∑ùë¶a\in D_{z}/D_{y}italic_a ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and a fortiori a‚ààint‚Å°(Dz/Dy)ùëéintsubscriptùê∑ùëßsubscriptùê∑ùë¶a\in\operatorname{int}(D_{z}/D_{y})italic_a ‚àà roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Consequently a‚ààDx‚à©int‚Å°(Dz/Dy)ùëésubscriptùê∑ùë•intsubscriptùê∑ùëßsubscriptùê∑ùë¶a\in D_{x}\cap\operatorname{int}(D_{z}/D_{y})italic_a ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à© roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Because we also have Dx‚à©int‚Å°(Dz/Dy)‚äÜDxsubscriptùê∑ùë•intsubscriptùê∑ùëßsubscriptùê∑ùë¶subscriptùê∑ùë•D_{x}\cap\operatorname{int}(D_{z}/D_{y})\subseteq D_{x}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à© roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚äÜ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, this shows that the MULTIPLICATION 2 rule is equivalence preserving.

The following example shows an interaction between all three MULTIPLICATION rules.

Example 7.1

Consider the CSP

‚ü®x‚ãÖy=z;x‚àà[1..20],y‚àà[9..11],z‚àà[155..161]‚ü©.delimited-‚ü®‚ü©formulae-sequence‚ãÖùë•ùë¶ùëßformulae-sequenceùë•delimited-[]1..20formulae-sequenceùë¶delimited-[]9..11ùëßdelimited-[]155..161{\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in[1..20],y\in[9..11],z\in[155..161]\rangle}.‚ü® italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x ‚àà [ 1..20 ] , italic_y ‚àà [ 9..11 ] , italic_z ‚àà [ 155..161 ] ‚ü© . (4)

To facilitate the reading we underline the modified domains. An application of the MULTIPLICATION 2 rule yields

‚ü®x‚ãÖy=z;x‚àà[16..16]¬Ø,y‚àà[9..11],z‚àà[155..161]‚ü©delimited-‚ü®‚ü©formulae-sequence‚ãÖùë•ùë¶ùëßformulae-sequenceùë•¬Ødelimited-[]16..16formulae-sequenceùë¶delimited-[]9..11ùëßdelimited-[]155..161{\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in\underline{[16..16]},y\in[9..11],z\in[155..161]\rangle}‚ü® italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x ‚àà under¬Ø start_ARG [ 16..16 ] end_ARG , italic_y ‚àà [ 9..11 ] , italic_z ‚àà [ 155..161 ] ‚ü©

since, as already noted in Subsection 3.2, [155..161]/[9..11])=[16..16][155..161]/[9..11])=[16..16][ 155..161 ] / [ 9..11 ] ) = [ 16..16 ], and [1..20]‚à©int‚Å°([16..16])=[16..16]delimited-[]1..20intdelimited-[]16..16delimited-[]16..16[1..20]\cap\operatorname{int}([16..16])=[16..16][ 1..20 ] ‚à© roman_int ( [ 16..16 ] ) = [ 16..16 ]. Applying now the MULTIPLICATION 3 rule we obtain

‚ü®x‚ãÖy=z;x‚àà[16..16],y‚àà[10..10]¬Ø,z‚àà[155..161]‚ü©delimited-‚ü®‚ü©formulae-sequence‚ãÖùë•ùë¶ùëßformulae-sequenceùë•delimited-[]16..16formulae-sequenceùë¶¬Ødelimited-[]10..10ùëßdelimited-[]155..161\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in[16..16],y\in\underline{[10..10]},z\in[155..161]\rangle‚ü® italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x ‚àà [ 16..16 ] , italic_y ‚àà under¬Ø start_ARG [ 10..10 ] end_ARG , italic_z ‚àà [ 155..161 ] ‚ü©

since [155..161]/[16..16]=[10..10]delimited-[]155..161delimited-[]16..16delimited-[]10..10[155..161]/[16..16]=[10..10][ 155..161 ] / [ 16..16 ] = [ 10..10 ] and [9..11]‚à©int‚Å°([10..10])=[10..10]delimited-[]9..11intdelimited-[]10..10delimited-[]10..10[9..11]\cap\operatorname{int}([10..10])=[10..10][ 9..11 ] ‚à© roman_int ( [ 10..10 ] ) = [ 10..10 ]. Next, by the application of the MULTIPLICATION 1 rule we obtain

‚ü®x‚ãÖy=z;x‚àà[16..16],y‚àà[10..10],z‚àà[160..160]¬Ø‚ü©delimited-‚ü®‚ü©formulae-sequence‚ãÖùë•ùë¶ùëßformulae-sequenceùë•delimited-[]16..16formulae-sequenceùë¶delimited-[]10..10ùëß¬Ødelimited-[]160..160\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in[16..16],y\in[10..10],z\in\underline{[160..160]}\rangle‚ü® italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x ‚àà [ 16..16 ] , italic_y ‚àà [ 10..10 ] , italic_z ‚àà under¬Ø start_ARG [ 160..160 ] end_ARG ‚ü©

since [16..16]‚ãÖ[10..10]=[160..160]‚ãÖdelimited-[]16..16delimited-[]10..10delimited-[]160..160[16..16]\cdot[10..10]=[160..160][ 16..16 ] ‚ãÖ [ 10..10 ] = [ 160..160 ] and [155..161]‚à©int‚Å°([160..160])=[160..160]delimited-[]155..161intdelimited-[]160..160delimited-[]160..160[155..161]\cap\operatorname{int}([160..160])=[160..160][ 155..161 ] ‚à© roman_int ( [ 160..160 ] ) = [ 160..160 ].

So using all three multiplication rules we could solve the CSP (4). ‚ñ°‚ñ°\Box‚ñ°

Now let us clarify why we did not define the division of the sets of integers ZùëçZitalic_Z and YùëåYitalic_Y by

Z/Y:={z/y‚ààùíµ‚à£y‚ààY,z‚ààZ,y‚â†0}.assignùëçùëåconditional-setùëßùë¶ùíµformulae-sequenceùë¶ùëåformulae-sequenceùëßùëçùë¶0Z/Y:=\mbox{$\{{z/y\in{\cal Z}\mid y\in Y,z\in Z,y\neq 0}\}$}.italic_Z / italic_Y := { italic_z / italic_y ‚àà caligraphic_Z ‚à£ italic_y ‚àà italic_Y , italic_z ‚àà italic_Z , italic_y ‚â† 0 } .

The reason is that in that case for any set of integers ZùëçZitalic_Z we would have Z/{0}=‚àÖùëç0Z/\mbox{$\{{0}\}$}=\mbox{$\emptyset$}italic_Z / { 0 } = ‚àÖ. Consequently, if we adopted this definition of the division of the integer intervals, the resulting MULTIPLICATION 2 and 3 rules would not be anymore equivalence preserving. Indeed, consider the CSP

‚ü®x‚ãÖy=z;x‚àà[‚àí2..1],y‚àà[0..0],z‚àà[‚àí8..10]‚ü©.delimited-‚ü®‚ü©formulae-sequence‚ãÖùë•ùë¶ùëßformulae-sequenceùë•delimited-[]2..1formulae-sequenceùë¶delimited-[]0..0ùëßdelimited-[]8..10\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in[-2..1],y\in[0..0],z\in[-8..10]\rangle.‚ü® italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x ‚àà [ - 2..1 ] , italic_y ‚àà [ 0..0 ] , italic_z ‚àà [ - 8..10 ] ‚ü© .

Then we would have [‚àí8..10]/[0..0]=‚àÖdelimited-[]8..10delimited-[]0..0[-8..10]/[0..0]=\mbox{$\emptyset$}[ - 8..10 ] / [ 0..0 ] = ‚àÖ and consequently by the MULTIPLICATION 2 rule we could conclude

‚ü®x‚ãÖy=z;x‚àà‚àÖ,y‚àà[0..0],z‚àà[‚àí8..10]‚ü©.delimited-‚ü®‚ü©formulae-sequence‚ãÖùë•ùë¶ùëßformulae-sequenceùë•formulae-sequenceùë¶delimited-[]0..0ùëßdelimited-[]8..10\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in\mbox{$\emptyset$},y\in[0..0],z\in[-8..10]\rangle.‚ü® italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x ‚àà ‚àÖ , italic_y ‚àà [ 0..0 ] , italic_z ‚àà [ - 8..10 ] ‚ü© .

So we reached an inconsistent CSP while the original CSP is consistent.

The transformation to atomic constraints can strengthen the reduction. Consider for example the simple constraint

w‚ãÖx‚ãÖy‚ãÖz=24‚ãÖùë§ùë•ùë¶ùëß24w\cdot x\cdot y\cdot z=24italic_w ‚ãÖ italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y ‚ãÖ italic_z = 24

with w=4ùë§4w=4italic_w = 4 and x,y,z‚àà[1..4]ùë•ùë¶ùëßdelimited-[]1..4x,y,z\in[1..4]italic_x , italic_y , italic_z ‚àà [ 1..4 ]. Application of the POLYNOMIAL EQUALITY rule does not reduce any of the domains, but if we replace the constraint with

u‚ãÖv=t,w‚ãÖx=u,y‚ãÖz=vformulae-sequence‚ãÖùë¢ùë£ùë°formulae-sequence‚ãÖùë§ùë•ùë¢‚ãÖùë¶ùëßùë£u\cdot v=t,\ w\cdot x=u,\ y\cdot z=vitalic_u ‚ãÖ italic_v = italic_t , italic_w ‚ãÖ italic_x = italic_u , italic_y ‚ãÖ italic_z = italic_v

with additional ranges t=24ùë°24t=24italic_t = 24, u‚àà[4..16]ùë¢delimited-[]4..16u\in[4..16]italic_u ‚àà [ 4..16 ], and v‚àà[1..16]ùë£delimited-[]1..16v\in[1..16]italic_v ‚àà [ 1..16 ], then by application of the MULTIPLICATION 3 rule to u‚ãÖv=t‚ãÖùë¢ùë£ùë°u\cdot v=titalic_u ‚ãÖ italic_v = italic_t we reduce the domain of vùë£vitalic_v to [2..6]delimited-[]2..6[2..6][ 2..6 ]. Next, by application of the MULTIPLICATION 2 rule to the same constraint we reduce the domain of uùë¢uitalic_u to [4..12]delimited-[]4..12[4..12][ 4..12 ], and finally by application of the MULTIPLICATION 3 rule to w‚ãÖx=u‚ãÖùë§ùë•ùë¢w\cdot x=uitalic_w ‚ãÖ italic_x = italic_u we reduce the domain of xùë•xitalic_x from [1..4]delimited-[]1..4[1..4][ 1..4 ] to [1..3]delimited-[]1..3[1..3][ 1..3 ]. Note, however, that this effect depends on the decomposition. If we had decomposed the constraint as

z‚ãÖ(y‚ãÖ(x‚ãÖw))=24‚ãÖùëß‚ãÖùë¶‚ãÖùë•ùë§24z\cdot(y\cdot(x\cdot w))=24italic_z ‚ãÖ ( italic_y ‚ãÖ ( italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_w ) ) = 24

with an auxiliary variable introduced for each pair of matching brackets, then we would not have been able to reduce any of the domains of xùë•xitalic_x, yùë¶yitalic_y, and zùëßzitalic_z.

In the remainder of the paper we will also consider variants of the full decomposition approach where we allow squaring and exponentiation as atomic constraints. For this purpose we explain the reasoning for the constraint x=ynùë•superscriptùë¶ùëõx=y^{n}italic_x = italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in the presence of the non-empty ranges x‚ààDxùë•subscriptùê∑ùë•x\in D_{x}italic_x ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and y‚ààDyùë¶subscriptùê∑ùë¶y\in D_{y}italic_y ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and for n>1ùëõ1n>1italic_n > 1. To this end we introduce the following two rules:

EXPONENTIATION

‚ü®x=yn;x‚ààDx,y‚ààDy‚ü©‚ü®x=yn;x‚ààDx‚Ä≤,y‚ààDy‚ü©delimited-‚ü®‚ü©formulae-sequenceùë•superscriptùë¶ùëõformulae-sequenceùë•subscriptùê∑ùë•ùë¶subscriptùê∑ùë¶delimited-‚ü®‚ü©formulae-sequenceùë•superscriptùë¶ùëõformulae-sequenceùë•superscriptsubscriptùê∑ùë•‚Ä≤ùë¶subscriptùê∑ùë¶\frac{\langle x=y^{n}\ ;\ x\in D_{x},y\in D_{y}\rangle}{\langle x=y^{n}\ ;\ x\in D_{x}^{\prime},y\in D_{y}\rangle}divide start_ARG ‚ü® italic_x = italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_x ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ü© end_ARG start_ARG ‚ü® italic_x = italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_x ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_y ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ü© end_ARG

ROOT EXTRACTION

‚ü®x=yn;x‚ààDx,y‚ààDy‚ü©‚ü®x=yn;x‚ààDx,y‚ààDy‚Ä≤‚ü©delimited-‚ü®‚ü©formulae-sequenceùë•superscriptùë¶ùëõformulae-sequenceùë•subscriptùê∑ùë•ùë¶subscriptùê∑ùë¶delimited-‚ü®‚ü©formulae-sequenceùë•superscriptùë¶ùëõformulae-sequenceùë•subscriptùê∑ùë•ùë¶superscriptsubscriptùê∑ùë¶‚Ä≤\frac{\langle x=y^{n}\ ;\ x\in D_{x},y\in D_{y}\rangle}{\langle x=y^{n}\ ;\ x\in D_{x},y\in D_{y}^{\prime}\rangle}divide start_ARG ‚ü® italic_x = italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_x ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ü© end_ARG start_ARG ‚ü® italic_x = italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_x ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ü© end_ARG

where Dx‚Ä≤:=Dx‚à©int‚Å°(Dyn)assignsuperscriptsubscriptùê∑ùë•‚Ä≤subscriptùê∑ùë•intsubscriptsuperscriptùê∑ùëõùë¶D_{x}^{\prime}:=D_{x}\cap\operatorname{int}(D^{n}_{y})italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à© roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), and Dy‚Ä≤:=int‚Å°(Dy‚à©Dxn)assignsuperscriptsubscriptùê∑ùë¶‚Ä≤intsubscriptùê∑ùë¶ùëõsubscriptùê∑ùë•D_{y}^{\prime}:=\operatorname{int}(D_{y}\cap\sqrt[n]{D_{x}})italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à© nth-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ).

To prove that these rules are equivalence preserving suppose that for some a‚ààDxùëésubscriptùê∑ùë•a\in D_{x}italic_a ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and b‚ààDyùëèsubscriptùê∑ùë¶b\in D_{y}italic_b ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT we have a=bnùëésuperscriptùëèùëõa=b^{n}italic_a = italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then a‚ààDynùëésuperscriptsubscriptùê∑ùë¶ùëõa\in D_{y}^{n}italic_a ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, so a‚ààint‚Å°(Dyn)ùëéintsuperscriptsubscriptùê∑ùë¶ùëõa\in\operatorname{int}(D_{y}^{n})italic_a ‚àà roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and consequently a‚ààDx‚à©int‚Å°(Dyn)ùëésubscriptùê∑ùë•intsuperscriptsubscriptùê∑ùë¶ùëõa\in D_{x}\cap\operatorname{int}(D_{y}^{n})italic_a ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à© roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Also b‚ààDxnùëèùëõsubscriptùê∑ùë•b\in\sqrt[n]{D_{x}}italic_b ‚àà nth-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG, so b‚ààDy‚à©Dxnùëèsubscriptùê∑ùë¶ùëõsubscriptùê∑ùë•b\in D_{y}\cap\sqrt[n]{D_{x}}italic_b ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à© nth-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG, and consequently b‚ààint‚Å°(Dy‚à©Dxn)ùëèintsubscriptùê∑ùë¶ùëõsubscriptùê∑ùë•b\in\operatorname{int}(D_{y}\cap\sqrt[n]{D_{x}})italic_b ‚àà roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à© nth-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ).

With exponentiation as an atomic constraint, full decomposition leads to idempotent rules, and the discussion at the end of Section¬†6 applies.

8 Relation to Hull and Box Consistency

In this section we relate the three approaches introduced above to the well-known methods for constraint propagation of arithmetic constraints on real variables, whose domains are represented by floating-point intervals. An overview of these methods is provided in [9]. Floating-point intervals are intervals of reals, with bounds from a finite set ‚Ñ±‚äÜ‚Ñõ‚à™{‚àí‚àû,‚àû}‚Ñ±‚Ñõ\mathcal{F}\subseteq\mathcal{R}\cup\{-\infty,\infty\}caligraphic_F ‚äÜ caligraphic_R ‚à™ { - ‚àû , ‚àû } of floating-point numbers that contains representations ‚àí‚àû-\infty- ‚àû and ‚àû\infty‚àû for plus and minus infinity. For floating-point intervals, the counterpart of the int‚Å°(‚ãÖ)int‚ãÖ\operatorname{int}(\cdot)roman_int ( ‚ãÖ ) operation is the hull of a set of real numbers defined as the smallest floating-point interval containing the set. Ideally, for an arithmetic constraint cùëêcitalic_c on the variables x1,‚Ä¶,xnsubscriptùë•1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëõx_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{n}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with respective floating-point interval domains D1,‚Ä¶,Dnsubscriptùê∑1‚Ä¶subscriptùê∑ùëõD_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},D_{n}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT we would like to enforce hull consistency, which entails that for all i‚àà[1..n]i\in[1..n]italic_i ‚àà [ 1 . . italic_n ]

Di=hull(xi‚àà‚Ñõ‚à£‚àÉx1‚ààD1,‚Ä¶,xi‚àí1‚ààDi‚àí1,xi+1‚ààDi+1,‚Ä¶,xn‚ààDn(x1,‚Ä¶,xn)‚ààC).\begin{array}[]{l@{\ }l}D_{i}=\operatorname{hull}(x_{i}\in\mathcal{R}\mid&\exists x_{1}\in D_{1},\ldots,x_{i-1}\in D_{i-1},x_{i+1}\in D_{i+1},\ldots,x_{n}\in D_{n}\\ &(x_{1},\ldots,x_{n})\in C).\end{array}start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_hull ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà caligraphic_R ‚à£ end_CELL start_CELL ‚àÉ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚àà italic_C ) . end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY

However, no efficient procedure exists for enforcing hull consistency on arbitrary arithmetic constraints. Therefore, the natural approach is to first decompose constraints into atomic constraints, each containing a single arithmetic operation. Maintaining hull consistency for the decomposed constraints can be done efficiently, using proof rules similar to the ones that we introduced, but hull consistency for the resulting decomposed CSP is a weaker notion of consistency than hull consistency for the original CSP.

Our full decomposition approach can be seen as the integer interval equivalent of the method for computing hull consistency for a decomposition that we just described, with the exception that linear constraints are not decomposed further. In the floating-point case, because of the accumulation of the rounding errors, the characterization of the resulting form of constraint propagation in terms of hull consistency is possible only if all constraints, including linear constraints, are decomposed into single-operator constraints.

To illustrate this consider the constraint x+y+z=wùë•ùë¶ùëßùë§x+y+z=witalic_x + italic_y + italic_z = italic_w with the variables ranging over the floating-point intervals Dx,Dy,Dzsubscriptùê∑ùë•subscriptùê∑ùë¶subscriptùê∑ùëßD_{x},D_{y},D_{z}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Dwsubscriptùê∑ùë§D_{w}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. When we evaluate Dx+Dy+Dzsubscriptùê∑ùë•subscriptùê∑ùë¶subscriptùê∑ùëßD_{x}+D_{y}+D_{z}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT using the floating-point interval arithmetic to compute an update for Dwsubscriptùê∑ùë§D_{w}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we have three options which two intervals to add first. Because the floating-point addition is non-associative, we actually compute the hull of a decomposition that has an extra variable added for either x+yùë•ùë¶x+yitalic_x + italic_y, x+zùë•ùëßx+zitalic_x + italic_z or y+zùë¶ùëßy+zitalic_y + italic_z, and the resulting interval is potentially a proper superset of hull‚Å°(Dx+Dy+Dz)hullsubscriptùê∑ùë•subscriptùê∑ùë¶subscriptùê∑ùëß\operatorname{hull}(D_{x}+D_{y}+D_{z})roman_hull ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Moreover, different rewritings of the constraint correspond to different decompositions, and although this need not be a problem in practice, the resulting form of local consistency is no longer clearly defined.

In contrast, for integer intervals, we do not need to deal with the accumulation of the rounding errors and the linear constraints can be left intact. Our other two approaches can be seen as variants of the full decomposition approach that exploit this property further: for partial decomposition we allow more than one multiplication per proof rule, and in the direct approach the decomposition is not made explicit at all. Apart from these variations, all three approaches are the same in one important aspect: multiple occurrences of the same variable are treated as different variables. To illustrate this, consider the constraint x3+x=0superscriptùë•3ùë•0x^{3}+x=0italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_x = 0, with x‚àà[‚àí1..1]ùë•delimited-[]1..1x\in[-1..1]italic_x ‚àà [ - 1..1 ]. While x=0ùë•0x=0italic_x = 0 is the unique solution, none of our three approaches will be able to reduce the domain of xùë•xitalic_x. The reason is that the two occurrences of xùë•xitalic_x are essentially treated as different variables in the reduction rules. This problem is known as the dependency problem of interval arithmetic.

In the context of constraints on reals [5] proposed to deal with the dependency problem using the notion of box consistency. It is a weaker notion of local consistency than hull consistency, but is potentially stronger than hull consistency for the decomposition of a constraint into atomic constraints (see, e.g., [9]). Enforcing box consistency, as described in [21], consists of fixing the domains of all variables except one, and then narrowing the domain of this variable by iteratively instantiating it with subdomains at the boundary of the original domain, each time verifying consistency of the constraint in the presence of the domains of the other variables, and subtracting the subdomain from the original domain if the instantiation leads to a failure.

The second step of the ‚Äòtrial-and-prune‚Äô procedure for enforcing box consistency that we just sketched can be implemented by enforcing hull consistency on a decomposition of the original constraint. So the procedure for enforcing box consistency can be seen as consisting of a number of procedures including the one that enforces hull consistency. One could apply the same technique to the arithmetic constraints on integer intervals, replacing the enforcement of hull consistency by one of our approaches to constraint propagation. This would lead to an integer equivalent of the box consistency. The efficiency of the resulting procedure depends on the choice of the underlying approach to constraint propagation, which provides another argument for the efficiency analysis of the approaches here considered.

9 A Characterization of the MULTIPLICATION Rules

It is useful to reflect on the effect of the proof rules used to achieve constraint propagation. In this section, by way of example, we focus on the MULTIPLICATION rules and characterize their effect using the notion of bounds consistency as defined in [16], limited to integer intervals. Let us recall first the definition that we adopt here to the multiplication constraint. Given an integer interval [l..h][l..h][ italic_l . . italic_h ] we denote by [l,h]ùëô‚Ñé[l,h][ italic_l , italic_h ] the corresponding real interval.

Definition 9.1

The CSP ‚ü®x‚ãÖy=z;x‚àà[lx..hx],y‚àà[ly..hy],z‚àà[lz..hz]‚ü©\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in[l_{x}..h_{x}],y\in[l_{y}..h_{y}],z\in[l_{z}..h_{z}]\rangle‚ü® italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x ‚àà [ italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . . italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] , italic_y ‚àà [ italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . . italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] , italic_z ‚àà [ italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . . italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ‚ü© is called bounds consistent if

  • ‚Ä¢

    ‚àÄa‚àà{lx,hx}‚Å¢‚àÉb‚àà[ly,hy]‚Å¢‚àÉc‚àà[lz,hz]‚Å¢a‚ãÖb=cfor-allùëésubscriptùëôùë•subscript‚Ñéùë•ùëèsubscriptùëôùë¶subscript‚Ñéùë¶ùëê‚ãÖsubscriptùëôùëßsubscript‚Ñéùëßùëéùëèùëê\mbox{$\forall$}a\in\mbox{$\{{l_{x},h_{x}}\}$}\ \mbox{$\exists$}b\in[l_{y},h_{y}]\ \mbox{$\exists$}c\in[l_{z},h_{z}]\ a\cdot b=c‚àÄ italic_a ‚àà { italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } ‚àÉ italic_b ‚àà [ italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ‚àÉ italic_c ‚àà [ italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] italic_a ‚ãÖ italic_b = italic_c,

  • ‚Ä¢

    ‚àÄb‚àà{ly,hy}‚Å¢‚àÉa‚àà[lx,hx]‚Å¢‚àÉc‚àà[lz,hz]‚Å¢a‚ãÖb=cfor-allùëèsubscriptùëôùë¶subscript‚Ñéùë¶ùëésubscriptùëôùë•subscript‚Ñéùë•ùëê‚ãÖsubscriptùëôùëßsubscript‚Ñéùëßùëéùëèùëê\mbox{$\forall$}b\in\mbox{$\{{l_{y},h_{y}}\}$}\ \mbox{$\exists$}a\in[l_{x},h_{x}]\ \mbox{$\exists$}c\in[l_{z},h_{z}]\ a\cdot b=c‚àÄ italic_b ‚àà { italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } ‚àÉ italic_a ‚àà [ italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ‚àÉ italic_c ‚àà [ italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] italic_a ‚ãÖ italic_b = italic_c,

  • ‚Ä¢

    ‚àÄc‚àà{lz,hz}‚Å¢‚àÉa‚àà[lx,hx]‚Å¢‚àÉb‚àà[ly,hy]‚Å¢a‚ãÖb=cfor-allùëêsubscriptùëôùëßsubscript‚Ñéùëßùëésubscriptùëôùë•subscript‚Ñéùë•ùëè‚ãÖsubscriptùëôùë¶subscript‚Ñéùë¶ùëéùëèùëê\mbox{$\forall$}c\in\mbox{$\{{l_{z},h_{z}}\}$}\ \mbox{$\exists$}a\in[l_{x},h_{x}]\ \mbox{$\exists$}b\in[l_{y},h_{y}]\ a\cdot b=c‚àÄ italic_c ‚àà { italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } ‚àÉ italic_a ‚àà [ italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ‚àÉ italic_b ‚àà [ italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] italic_a ‚ãÖ italic_b = italic_c. ‚ñ°‚ñ°\Box‚ñ°

The following result entails that the MULTIPLICATION rules will not reduce a CSP beyond bounds consistency.

Theorem 9.2 (Bounds consistency)

Suppose a CSP ‚ü®x‚ãÖy=z;x‚ààDx,y‚ààDy,z‚ààDz‚ü©delimited-‚ü®‚ü©formulae-sequencenormal-‚ãÖùë•ùë¶ùëßformulae-sequenceùë•subscriptùê∑ùë•formulae-sequenceùë¶subscriptùê∑ùë¶ùëßsubscriptùê∑ùëß\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in D_{x},y\in D_{y},z\in D_{z}\rangle‚ü® italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ü© with the integer interval domains is bounds consistent. Then it is closed under the applications of the MULTIPLICATION 1,2 and 3 rules.

Proof.¬†See the Appendix. ‚ñ°‚ñ°\Box‚ñ°

This theorem shows that the MULTIPLICATION rules entail a notion of local consistency, say MùëÄMitalic_M-consistency, that is implied by bounds consistency. However, MùëÄMitalic_M-consistency does not imply bounds consistency. Here is an example. Consider the CSP

‚ü®x‚ãÖy=z;x‚àà[‚àí2..1],y‚àà[‚àí3..10],z‚àà[8..10]‚ü©.delimited-‚ü®‚ü©formulae-sequence‚ãÖùë•ùë¶ùëßformulae-sequenceùë•delimited-[]2..1formulae-sequenceùë¶delimited-[]3..10ùëßdelimited-[]8..10\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in[-2..1],y\in[-3..10],z\in[8..10]\rangle.‚ü® italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x ‚àà [ - 2..1 ] , italic_y ‚àà [ - 3..10 ] , italic_z ‚àà [ 8..10 ] ‚ü© .

It is not bounds consistent, since for y=‚àí3ùë¶3y=-3italic_y = - 3 no real values a‚àà[‚àí2,1]ùëé21a\in[-2,1]italic_a ‚àà [ - 2 , 1 ] and c‚àà[8,10]ùëê810c\in[8,10]italic_c ‚àà [ 8 , 10 ] exist such that a‚ãÖ(‚àí3)=c‚ãÖùëé3ùëêa\cdot(-3)=citalic_a ‚ãÖ ( - 3 ) = italic_c. Indeed, it is easy to check that

{y‚àà‚Ñõ‚à£‚àÉx‚àà[‚àí2,1]‚Å¢‚àÉz‚àà[8,10]‚Å¢x‚ãÖy=z}=(‚àí‚àû,‚àí4]‚à™[8,‚àû).conditional-setùë¶‚Ñõùë•21ùëß‚ãÖ810ùë•ùë¶ùëß48\mbox{$\{{y\in{\cal R}\mid\mbox{$\exists$}x\in[-2,1]\>\mbox{$\exists$}z\in[8,10]\>x\cdot y=z}\}$}=(-\infty,-4]\cup[8,\infty).{ italic_y ‚àà caligraphic_R ‚à£ ‚àÉ italic_x ‚àà [ - 2 , 1 ] ‚àÉ italic_z ‚àà [ 8 , 10 ] italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y = italic_z } = ( - ‚àû , - 4 ] ‚à™ [ 8 , ‚àû ) .

However, this CSP is closed under the applications of the MULTIPLICATION 1, 2 and 3 rules since

  • ‚Ä¢

    [8..10]‚äÜint‚Å°([‚àí2..1]‚ãÖ[‚àí3..10])delimited-[]8..10int‚ãÖdelimited-[]2..1delimited-[]3..10[8..10]\mbox{$\>\subseteq\>$}\operatorname{int}([-2..1]\cdot[-3..10])[ 8..10 ] ‚äÜ roman_int ( [ - 2..1 ] ‚ãÖ [ - 3..10 ] ), as int‚Å°([‚àí2..1]‚ãÖ[‚àí3..10])=[‚àí20..10]int‚ãÖdelimited-[]2..1delimited-[]3..10delimited-[]20..10\operatorname{int}([-2..1]\cdot[-3..10])=[-20..10]roman_int ( [ - 2..1 ] ‚ãÖ [ - 3..10 ] ) = [ - 20..10 ],

  • ‚Ä¢

    [‚àí2..1]‚äÜint‚Å°([8..10]/[‚àí3..10])delimited-[]2..1intdelimited-[]8..10delimited-[]3..10[-2..1]\mbox{$\>\subseteq\>$}\operatorname{int}([8..10]/[-3..10])[ - 2..1 ] ‚äÜ roman_int ( [ 8..10 ] / [ - 3..10 ] ) as int‚Å°([8..10]/[‚àí3..10])=[‚àí10..10]intdelimited-[]8..10delimited-[]3..10delimited-[]10..10\operatorname{int}([8..10]/[-3..10])=[-10..10]roman_int ( [ 8..10 ] / [ - 3..10 ] ) = [ - 10..10 ], and

  • ‚Ä¢

    [‚àí3..10]‚äÜint‚Å°([8..10]/[‚àí2..1])delimited-[]3..10intdelimited-[]8..10delimited-[]2..1[-3..10]\mbox{$\>\subseteq\>$}\operatorname{int}([8..10]/[-2..1])[ - 3..10 ] ‚äÜ roman_int ( [ 8..10 ] / [ - 2..1 ] ) as int‚Å°([8..10]/[‚àí2..1])=[‚àí10..10]intdelimited-[]8..10delimited-[]2..1delimited-[]10..10\operatorname{int}([8..10]/[-2..1])=[-10..10]roman_int ( [ 8..10 ] / [ - 2..1 ] ) = [ - 10..10 ].

The following result clarifies that this example identifies the only cause of discrepancy between MùëÄMitalic_M-consistency and bounds consistency. Here, given an integer interval D:=[l..h]D:=[l..h]italic_D := [ italic_l . . italic_h ] we define ‚ü®D‚ü©:={x‚ààùíµ‚à£l<x<h}assigndelimited-‚ü®‚ü©ùê∑conditional-setùë•ùíµùëôùë•‚Ñé\langle D\rangle:=\mbox{$\{{x\in{\cal Z}\mid l<x<h}\}$}‚ü® italic_D ‚ü© := { italic_x ‚àà caligraphic_Z ‚à£ italic_l < italic_x < italic_h }.

Theorem 9.3 (Bounds consistency 2)

Consider a CSP œï:=‚ü®x‚ãÖy=z;x‚ààDx,y‚ààDy,z‚ààDz‚ü©assignitalic-œïdelimited-‚ü®‚ü©formulae-sequencenormal-‚ãÖùë•ùë¶ùëßformulae-sequenceùë•subscriptùê∑ùë•formulae-sequenceùë¶subscriptùê∑ùë¶ùëßsubscriptùê∑ùëß\phi:=\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in D_{x},y\in D_{y},z\in D_{z}\rangleitalic_œï := ‚ü® italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ü© with non-empty integer interval domains and such that

0‚àà‚ü®Dx‚ü©‚à©‚ü®Dy‚ü©¬†implies¬†0‚ààDz.0‚àà‚ü®Dx‚ü©‚à©‚ü®Dy‚ü©¬†implies¬†0‚ààDz\mbox{$0\in\langle D_{x}\rangle\cap\langle D_{y}\rangle$ implies $0\in D_{z}$}.0 ‚àà ‚ü® italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ü© ‚à© ‚ü® italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ü© implies 0 ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (5)

Suppose œïitalic-œï\phiitalic_œï is closed under the applications of the MULTIPLICATION 1,2 and 3 rules. Then it is bounds consistent.

Proof.¬†See the Appendix. ‚ñ°‚ñ°\Box‚ñ°

Consequently the MULTIPLICATION rules only fail to enforce bounds consistency for the constraint x‚ãÖy=z‚ãÖùë•ùë¶ùëßx\cdot y=zitalic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y = italic_z in case the domains of xùë•xitalic_x and yùë¶yitalic_y are both of the form [l..h][l..h][ italic_l . . italic_h ], with l<0ùëô0l<0italic_l < 0 and h>0‚Ñé0h>0italic_h > 0 while zùëßzitalic_z can assume either only positive numbers, or only negative numbers. Because the zeroes in the domains of xùë•xitalic_x and yùë¶yitalic_y do not contribute to any solution, we can remedy this effect by temporarily splitting these domains in a positive interval and a negative interval. Bounds consistency for the constraint x‚ãÖy=z‚ãÖùë•ùë¶ùëßx\cdot y=zitalic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y = italic_z is then achieved by applying the MULTIPLICATION rules to the resulting subproblems, and updating the domain of each variable with the int‚Å°(‚ãÖ)int‚ãÖ\operatorname{int}(\cdot)roman_int ( ‚ãÖ ) closure of the union of its domain in these subproblems.

In [20] similar rules to our MULTIPLICATION rules are defined that apply this technique directly. They were defined without the use of interval arithmetic. It is also shown there that the LINEAR EQUALITY and LINEAR INEQUALITY rules enforce bounds consistency.

10 Implementation Details

10.1 Weak Division

We already mentioned in Section 3 that the division operation on the intervals does not admit an efficient implementation. The reason is that the int‚Å°(‚ãÖ)int‚ãÖ\operatorname{int}(\cdot)roman_int ( ‚ãÖ ) closure of the interval division [a..b]/[c..d][a..b]/[c..d][ italic_a . . italic_b ] / [ italic_c . . italic_d ] requires an auxiliary computation in case when 0‚àâ[c..d]0\not\in[c..d]0 ‚àâ [ italic_c . . italic_d ]. The preprocessing of [c..d][c..d][ italic_c . . italic_d ] becomes impractical for small intervals [a..b][a..b][ italic_a . . italic_b ], and large [c..d][c..d][ italic_c . . italic_d ], occurring for example for the constraint ‚àèi=1nxi=‚àèi=1nisuperscriptsubscriptproductùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùë•ùëñsuperscriptsubscriptproductùëñ1ùëõùëñ\prod_{i=1}^{n}x_{i}=\prod_{i=1}^{n}i‚àè start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ‚àè start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i, of the benchmark problem mentioned in Subsection¬†1.1. This can be remedied by using the following variant of the division operation. We call it weak division since it yields a larger set (and so is ‚Äòweaker‚Äô).

[a..b]:[c..d]:={[‚åàmin(A)‚åâ..‚åämax(A)‚åã]if¬†0‚àâ[c..d], orif¬†0‚àâ[a..b]¬†and¬†0‚àà{c,d}¬†and¬†c<d,[a..b]/[c..d]otherwise[a..b]:[c..d]:=\left\{\begin{tabular}[]{ll}$[\left\lceil\operatorname{min}(A)\right\rceil..\left\lfloor\operatorname{max}(A)\right\rfloor]$&\mbox{if $0\not\in[c..d]$, or}\\ &\mbox{\phantom{if} $0\notin[a..b]$} and $0\in\{c,d\}$ and $c<d$,\\ $[a..b]/[c..d]$&otherwise\end{tabular}\right.[ italic_a . . italic_b ] : [ italic_c . . italic_d ] := { start_ROW start_CELL [ ‚åà roman_min ( italic_A ) ‚åâ . . ‚åä roman_max ( italic_A ) ‚åã ] end_CELL start_CELL if 0‚àâ[c..d], or end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL if 0‚àâ[a..b] and 0 ‚àà { italic_c , italic_d } and italic_c < italic_d , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL [ italic_a . . italic_b ] / [ italic_c . . italic_d ] end_CELL start_CELL otherwise end_CELL end_ROW

where A={a/c‚Ä≤,a/d‚Ä≤,b/c‚Ä≤,b/d‚Ä≤}ùê¥ùëésuperscriptùëê‚Ä≤ùëésuperscriptùëë‚Ä≤ùëèsuperscriptùëê‚Ä≤ùëèsuperscriptùëë‚Ä≤A=\mbox{$\{{a/c^{\prime},a/d^{\prime},b/c^{\prime},b/d^{\prime}}\}$}italic_A = { italic_a / italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a / italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_b / italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_b / italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT }, and [c‚Ä≤..d‚Ä≤]=[c..d]‚àí{0}[c^{\prime}..d^{\prime}]=[c..d]-\{0\}[ italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . . italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] = [ italic_c . . italic_d ] - { 0 }.

Then int([a..b]:[c..d])\operatorname{int}([a..b]:[c..d])roman_int ( [ italic_a . . italic_b ] : [ italic_c . . italic_d ] ) can be computed by a straightforward case analysis already used for int([a..b]/[c..d])\operatorname{int}([a..b]/[c..d])roman_int ( [ italic_a . . italic_b ] / [ italic_c . . italic_d ] ) but now without any auxiliary computation. The weak division operator gives rise to the following versions of the MULTIPLICATION rules 2 and 3:

MULTIPLICATION 2w

‚ü®x‚ãÖy=z;x‚ààDx,y‚ààDy,z‚ààDz‚ü©‚ü®x‚ãÖy=z;x‚ààDx‚Ä≤,y‚ààDy,z‚ààDz‚ü©delimited-‚ü®‚ü©formulae-sequence‚ãÖùë•ùë¶ùëßformulae-sequenceùë•subscriptùê∑ùë•formulae-sequenceùë¶subscriptùê∑ùë¶ùëßsubscriptùê∑ùëßdelimited-‚ü®‚ü©formulae-sequence‚ãÖùë•ùë¶ùëßformulae-sequenceùë•superscriptsubscriptùê∑ùë•‚Ä≤formulae-sequenceùë¶subscriptùê∑ùë¶ùëßsubscriptùê∑ùëß\frac{\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in D_{x},y\in D_{y},z\in D_{z}\rangle}{\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in D_{x}^{\prime},y\in D_{y},z\in D_{z}\rangle}divide start_ARG ‚ü® italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ü© end_ARG start_ARG ‚ü® italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_y ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ü© end_ARG

MULTIPLICATION 3w

‚ü®x‚ãÖy=z;x‚ààDx,y‚ààDy,z‚ààDz‚ü©‚ü®x‚ãÖy=z;x‚ààDx,y‚ààDy‚Ä≤,z‚ààDz‚ü©delimited-‚ü®‚ü©formulae-sequence‚ãÖùë•ùë¶ùëßformulae-sequenceùë•subscriptùê∑ùë•formulae-sequenceùë¶subscriptùê∑ùë¶ùëßsubscriptùê∑ùëßdelimited-‚ü®‚ü©formulae-sequence‚ãÖùë•ùë¶ùëßformulae-sequenceùë•subscriptùê∑ùë•formulae-sequenceùë¶superscriptsubscriptùê∑ùë¶‚Ä≤ùëßsubscriptùê∑ùëß\frac{\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in D_{x},y\in D_{y},z\in D_{z}\rangle}{\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in D_{x},y\in D_{y}^{\prime},z\in D_{z}\rangle}divide start_ARG ‚ü® italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ü© end_ARG start_ARG ‚ü® italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_z ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ü© end_ARG

where Dx‚Ä≤:=Dx‚à©int‚Å°(Dz:Dy)assignsuperscriptsubscriptùê∑ùë•‚Ä≤subscriptùê∑ùë•int:subscriptùê∑ùëßsubscriptùê∑ùë¶D_{x}^{\prime}:=D_{x}\cap\operatorname{int}(D_{z}:D_{y})italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à© roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), and Dy‚Ä≤:=Dy‚à©int‚Å°(Dz:Dx)assignsuperscriptsubscriptùê∑ùë¶‚Ä≤subscriptùê∑ùë¶int:subscriptùê∑ùëßsubscriptùê∑ùë•D_{y}^{\prime}:=D_{y}\cap\operatorname{int}(D_{z}:D_{x})italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à© roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

In the assumed framework based on constraint propagation and tree search, all domains become eventually singletons or empty sets. It can easily be verified that both division operations are then equal, i.e., [a..b]:[c..d]=[a..b]/[c..d][a..b]:[c..d]=[a..b]/[c..d][ italic_a . . italic_b ] : [ italic_c . . italic_d ] = [ italic_a . . italic_b ] / [ italic_c . . italic_d ], for a‚â•bùëéùëèa\geq bitalic_a ‚â• italic_b and c‚â•dùëêùëëc\geq ditalic_c ‚â• italic_d. For this reason, we can safely replace any of the reduction rules introduced in this paper, notably POLYNOMIAL EQUALITY, POLYNOMIAL INEQUALITY, and MULTIPLICATION 2 and 3, by their counterparts based on the weak division. For the MULTIPLICATION rules specifically, the following theorem states that both sets of rules actually achieve the same constraint propagation.

Theorem 10.1 (MULTIPLICATION)

A CSP ‚ü®x‚ãÖy=z;x‚ààDx,y‚ààDy,z‚ààDz‚ü©delimited-‚ü®‚ü©formulae-sequencenormal-‚ãÖùë•ùë¶ùëßformulae-sequenceùë•subscriptùê∑ùë•formulae-sequenceùë¶subscriptùê∑ùë¶ùëßsubscriptùê∑ùëß\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in D_{x},y\in D_{y},z\in D_{z}\rangle‚ü® italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ü© with the integer interval domains is closed under the applications of the MULTIPLICATION 1, 2 and 3 rules iff it is closed under the applications of the MULTIPLICATION 1, 2w and 3w rules.

Proof.¬†See the Appendix. ‚ñ°‚ñ°\Box‚ñ°


Let us clarify now the relation between the MULTIPLICATION rules and the corresponding rules based on real interval arithmetic combined with the rounding of the resulting real intervals inwards to the largest integer intervals. The CSP ‚ü®x‚ãÖy=z;x‚àà[‚àí3..3],y‚àà[‚àí1..1],z‚àà[1..2]‚ü©delimited-‚ü®‚ü©formulae-sequence‚ãÖùë•ùë¶ùëßformulae-sequenceùë•delimited-[]3..3formulae-sequenceùë¶delimited-[]1..1ùëßdelimited-[]1..2\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in[-3..3],y\in[-1..1],z\in[1..2]\rangle‚ü® italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x ‚àà [ - 3..3 ] , italic_y ‚àà [ - 1..1 ] , italic_z ‚àà [ 1..2 ] ‚ü©, which we already discussed in the introduction, shows that these approaches yield different results. Indeed, using the MULTIPLICATION rule 2 we can reduce the domain of xùë•xitalic_x to [‚àí2..2]delimited-[]2..2[-2..2][ - 2..2 ], while the latter approach yields no reduction.

On the other hand, the applications of the MULTIPLICATION rules 2w and 3w to ‚ü®x‚ãÖy=z;x‚ààDx,y‚ààDy,z‚ààDz‚ü©delimited-‚ü®‚ü©formulae-sequence‚ãÖùë•ùë¶ùëßformulae-sequenceùë•subscriptùê∑ùë•formulae-sequenceùë¶subscriptùê∑ùë¶ùëßsubscriptùê∑ùëß\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in D_{x},y\in D_{y},z\in D_{z}\rangle‚ü® italic_x ‚ãÖ italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z ‚àà italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ü© such that int‚Å°(Dz:Dx)‚â†int‚Å°(Dz/Dx)int:subscriptùê∑ùëßsubscriptùê∑ùë•intsubscriptùê∑ùëßsubscriptùê∑ùë•\operatorname{int}(D_{z}:D_{x})\neq\operatorname{int}(D_{z}/D_{x})roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚â† roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and int‚Å°(Dz:Dy)‚â†int‚Å°(Dz/Dy)int:subscriptùê∑ùëßsubscriptùê∑ùë¶intsubscriptùê∑ùëßsubscriptùê∑ùë¶\operatorname{int}(D_{z}:D_{y})\neq\operatorname{int}(D_{z}/D_{y})roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚â† roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (so in cases when the use of the weak interval division differs from the use of the interval division) do coincide with the just discussed approach based on real interval arithmetic and inward rounding. This is a consequence of the way the multiplication and division of real intervals are defined, see [15]. However, as we already stated in the introduction, we believe that the limited precision of floating-point interval arithmetic, and the modest overhead of arbitrary length integers justify a separate implementation of these rules for arithmetic constraints on integer intervals.

10.2 Implementation

Platform

Our experiments were performed using OpenSolver¬†[23], an experimental constraint solver based on constraint propagation and tree search. OpenSolver can be configured by software plug-ins in a number of predefined categories, corresponding to different aspects of constraint propagation and tree search, which makes it particularly well-suited for carrying out comparative studies of implementations of constraint solvers. The categories of plug-ins that are relevant for the experiments reported here are:

  • ‚Ä¢

    variable domain types, which implement the domains of variables,

  • ‚Ä¢

    domain reduction functions (DRFs), which correspond to the reduction rules,

  • ‚Ä¢

    schedulers of DRFs, which determine the order in which the DRFs are applied,

  • ‚Ä¢

    branching strategies, which split the search tree after constraint propagation has terminated, and

  • ‚Ä¢

    several categories corresponding to different aspects of a search strategy that determine how to traverse a search tree.

All experiments were performed using the IntegerInterval variable domain type plug-in. Domains of this type consist of an indication of the type of the interval (bounded, unbounded, left/right-bounded, or empty), and a pair of arbitrary length integer bounds.
